TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Earlier this week the Senate resolved that I should table certain documents that were being held by my department and also documents being held by the Australian Heritage Commission. Notwithstanding the fact that only six hours notice was given from the time of passage of the resolution to when the Senate ordered the documents to be produced, which was quite incredible, officials have worked long and hard to gather these documents—in one night, I know, working until 3 a.m. It has been at obviously quite a considerable cost—many thousands of dollars. Nevertheless, I obtained the documents yesterday and was able to check them last night.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, however, a number of the documents are `owned'—if it is the right expression—by other ministers, in particular the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson. He was out of Canberra last night and is returning to Canberra about now, and it is not my intention to table them until he has had an opportunity to look at them. I think that is not only the courteous way to proceed but also in accordance with normal practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent her moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion of censure of the Minister for the Environment in relation to his failure to comply with an order of the Senate for the production of documents.

The reason I have moved this motion is that it is a very serious matter. Just now we have had the Minister for the Environment indicat ing that there was six hours notice. That is patently untrue. The notice was given on Wednesday, 14 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the motion passed?

—Wednesday, 14 May was when the notice was given. I agreed to a request from Senator Hill on Thursday, 15 May—the day on which I would have sought to have the motion declared formal—to defer consideration of the motion for one week. You would think that any reasonable person, having asked for a deferral, would be saying, `Yes; let's get this under way; let's get this prepared; let's get people looking at the documents.' Oh, no. He said, `Let's wait until the last six hours and let's turn around to the Senate and try and give that story to the Senate'—as if that is the correct way for a minister to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: I deferred for one week and I believed it was a very reasonable action. On Monday, 26 May, the Senate agreed to the motion calling for the production of these documents. On Wednesday, 27 May, the same Senator Hill made a statement saying, `Yesterday, the Senate ordered that I table certain documents in the Senate'. He said, `I wanted to advise the Senate that my department is moving expeditiously' and that he would have them ready for the Senate `tomorrow'. That was Wednesday. `Tomorrow' came and went.

We have now been told that they are now beginning to think that they might belong to other ministers. This is a nonsense. When those documents were mentioned on 14 May it might have been a good time to check with other ministers, if those documents were collected from other ministers. This is contempt of the Senate. What is happening is that the minister is trying to bury his own complicity in this whole shoddy nonsense.

Do you remember the debate which actually led to the issue in the first place? The debate was about advice that was given by the Australian Heritage Commission in 1994. The minister said, `You're wrong; I have got more up‐to‐date advice.' So it is an entirely reasonable thing for the Senate to ask for that more up‐to‐date advice if that minister is going to use the fact that he has more up‐to‐date advice in a debate to say that I am wrong, that he and the states have done the right thing in relation to their decisions to propose to woodchip an extraordinarily ecologically valuable piece of forest in the south‐west of Western Australia. It was the minister himself who said, `I have got more up‐to‐date advice from the Australian Heritage Commission. They have been fully part of the process.' Isn't it reasonable for the Senate to say, `Okay, you say they have been fully part of the process; you've got more up‐to‐date advice; where is it?'

That is the contempt of the Senate. I did not even receive a phone call about this this morning. I could not get the minister on the phone last night because he did not return the call to say that this is what was going to happen this morning. All I knew was that he was taking the documents home. Wouldn't you think somebody in that department would have thought, `Oh, these documents belong to other ministers'? This is a nonsense. Somebody is trying to bury information in this process. And guess what? We will end up with a whole list—if we ever get the documents—of those things which somehow or other have got a little query on them saying `commercial‐in‐confidence'. What it means is `buried' or `trying to hide'.

That is what the delay is. The delay is in somebody searching for anything that might actually led to the conclusion which most of us know is true: that the Australian Heritage Commission have not been fully involved in this process and have been very concerned, and that the federal bodies have not been doing the right thing. If this is not the case, come clean. In the meantime, I urge the Senate to support this motion. You will not hear the last of me until we receive every one of those documents.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

The minister was held up in an all‐day meeting with environment groups from all around Australia. Senator Margetts, I would imagine, was suggesting that Senator Hill should have withdrawn from the meeting with the national environment groups so that he could have gone back to his office and gone through a half‐foot high pile of documents just to satisfy her demands.

WINE EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to introduce a charge on exports of Australian wine to assist in funding the wine export promotion infrastructure and program of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (the corporation). The government is introducing the charge at the request of the wine industry.

The corporation's statutory responsibilities include wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine.

The corporation is currently funded by levies paid under the Wine Grapes Levy Act 1979. In recent years it has also received financial support for export promotion through grants from state and Commonwealth governments.

The wine industry developed the export charge proposal because it was concerned that the corporation would have to wind down its generic export promotion program for Australian wine as the grant funding came to an end. The industry strongly supports the corporation's export promotion program, and regards it as an essential component of its export growth strategy. It does not believe that a voluntary scheme would be effective.

Introduction of the wine export charge will ensure continued funding for generic wine export promotion. The export charge is expected to raise about $1 million per year to fund the infrastructure and part of the promotion program costs of the Australian Wine Export Council (the council). Exporters participating in major promotions also contribute directly to meet part of the cost. The council, a committee of the corporation, oversees the corporation's export promotion program.
The wine export charge will have no impact on the Commonwealth budget.
The wine industry has demonstrated its support for the export charge proposal in a number of ways.

At successive annual general meetings of the corporation, in 1995 and 1996, levy payers to the corporation have considered motions in support of the wine export charge. All levy payers are entitled to vote at the annual general meeting, with votes allocated according to the dollar amount of levy paid. The motion was circulated to all levy payers prior to the meetings. At the last meeting in December 1996, 94 per cent of votes were in favour of the proposal. There was strong support for the proposal from small, medium and large producers.
The government has also received many representations from individual winemakers and industry bodies, including the corporation, requesting the introduction of the charge.

On taking office, the government had to consider a number of proposals from primary industries for new levies and charges. It decided that a more systematic process was needed for assessing such proposals, and decided to develop a set of principles for the purposes of this assessment.

In developing the levies principles, the government was concerned to ensure that there was a strong case and a high level of support for proposals from industry for new levies and charges. It wanted to be satisfied on a number of points, including that such proposals relate to a function for which there is a significant market failure, have broad support within the industry, and have been the subject of extensive consultation with all industry sectors.
The government has assessed the wine export charge against the levies principles and is satisfied that it meets all relevant principles.

As honourable senators are aware, the Australian wine industry is currently enjoying unprecedented international recognition and is achieving rapid growth in exports. Between 1985/86 and 1995/96, exports grew more than ten‐fold in volume and more than twenty‐fold in value, from 11 million litres worth $21 million to 130 million litres worth $471 million. Australia's major export markets are Europe, North America and New Zealand.

In calendar year 1996, exports totalled 148 million litres valued at $551 million. This is an increase on the previous year of 28 per cent by volume and 36 per cent by value. Exports now account for over 28 per cent of production. This growth in exports is being accomplished in spite of falling world production and consumption.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has projected that by 2001/02, wine exports will more than double in volume to 407 million litres valued at $1.5 billion, which is equivalent to $1.3 billion in 1996/97 dollars.
The Australian wine industry has set a goal in its industry plan entitled `Strategy 2025' to achieve annual sales of $4.5 billion by the year 2025 of which exports would make up $2.5 billion.

The industry believes that generic promotion of Australian wine in export markets will continue to make an important contribution to the achievement of its goals, and is prepared to fund this promotion.

The wine industry has developed an exciting vision for its long‐term future in `Strategy 2025'. Through its support for the wine export charge, the industry has demonstrated it is committed to future growth and development through exports. The government wishes the industry every success in this important endeavour.
I commend this bill to honourable senators, and present the explanatory memorandum.
WINE EXPORT CHARGE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

The bill amends the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 (the Corporation Act) and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 (the Collection Act). These amendments are required as a result of the enactment of the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997.

The Corporation Act is amended in several ways: firstly, to include payers of the wine export charge in the arrangements for the Corporation's annual general meeting. This will enable them to have the right to represent their interests at annual general meetings of the Corporation and to receive the services and information that the Corporation provides to its levy payers. Secondly, to include wine export charge funds in the arrangements for payments between the Commonwealth and the Corporation; and finally to extend to the wine export charge the arrangements which enable the Corporation to provide information in order to assist and make savings in the levy collection process.

The Collection Act is amended so that the arrangements under that act for the collection of levies and charges are extended to the wine export charge, to enable it to be collected in an efficient and effective manner.
I commend the bill to honourable senators, and present the explanatory memorandum.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (INFRASTRUCTURE BORROWINGS) BILL 1997
The Infrastructure Borrowing tax concession was first introduced by the previous government as part of their 1992 One Nation statement. It was extended in the 1994 Working Nation statement.

The intention of the infrastructure borrowings tax concession was to allow companies reduced costs of borrowing to finance the construction of infrastructure projects. This was achieved by the borrower forgoing deductions for the cost of the borrowing, such as interest, and the lender being exempt from tax in respect of gains from borrowing, such as corresponding interest income, or eligible for a tax rebate of 36 per cent. The intention was for lenders to pass these benefits back to the project via a lower interest rate on the borrowings.

To be eligible to use the infrastructure borrowing tax concession, an infrastructure project must be certified by the Development Allowance Authority. In the period between 1994 and 30 June 1996, the Development Allowance Authority issued certificates for 12 infrastructure borrowing projects with a total borrowing of $4 billion. At 30 June 1996, it also had six applications on hand with total borrowings of at least $2.6 billion. Over the six weeks prior to the 1996-97 budget, the Development Allowance Authority received applications for a further 71 projects with estimated borrowings of around $21.6 billion. If all these applications were certified, the revenue cost over the period 1996-97 to 1998-99 has been estimated to exceed $4 billion.

Because of tax aggressive financing arrangements intended to be implemented in association with some of these applications, much of the revenue lost would be captured by financiers and high marginal tax rate investors rather than the intended recipients, the infrastructure projects themselves.
Against that background, the Treasurer announced on 14 February 1997 the cessation of the infrastructure borrowing tax concession.
This bill contains amendments to the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 that are necessary to wind up the concession.

The bill prevents the Development Allowance Authority from issuing any certificates to infrastructure projects after 12.00pm on 14 February 1997. However, where an infrastructure project had received, prior to that time, advice from the Development Allowance Authority that it would be issued with a certificate subject to specified undertakings, the Development Allowance Authority will be permitted to issue a certificate.

Under the present law, conditions on existing certificates can be varied. However, a variation after 12.00pm on 14 February 1997 will not be permitted where the Commissioner of Taxation determines that the variation is likely to cause an increased cost to the revenue.
The bill will not otherwise affect already issued certificates continuing and operating unchanged.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable Senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Reform of Employment Services Bill 1996 [1997] and the Reform of Employment Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1996 [1997] repeal in full the Employment Services Act 1994, which enacted the Labor Party's Working Nation approach—the provision of labour market programs and case management—for the long‐term unemployed. These bills represent a very radical change in direction for employment services in Australia. The changes have been shrouded in positive rhetoric. However, these bills and the minister's second reading speech are totally silent on many important issues. It is only through analysis of the omissions to this proposed legislation that we learn what it is really about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party has serious concerns about the government's new direction for employment services in Australia. We are not opposed to the introduction of further competition into employment services. Labor, under its Working Nation program, introduced competition to employment services, and that proved successful in the provision of case management. Labor did that while strengthening the role of the public provider in ensuring fundamental community service obligations were delivered for the unemployed.

Rather than take a further measured step along the road to increased competition in the provision of employment services, this government has elected to radically overthrow the current arrangements in a most imprudent way. These bills are allegedly about creating a market for employment assistance services. Their impact, however, is far wider and far more fundamental.

These bills, if enacted unamended, would remove the commitment to seek full employ ment, end universal access to free labour exchange services, abolish the legislative guarantee of a public provider of employment services, exclude approximately one‐third of job seekers from anything but self‐help facilities, omit any legislative guarantee to meet employment services needs in rural and regional areas, distribute $1 billion of public funds to private providers operating in a new market without adequate safeguards, fail to guarantee quality of services or rights of access for job seekers—in a regime that militates against training and secure long‐term job placements—and create a market where all job seekers who are not publicly subsidised will end up having to pay for employment services. All this comes in a budget context of reduced funding and rationing of limited services.

The government would have us believe that allocating fewer funds to a new, untested market for distributing assistance to a rationed number of unemployed persons represents a serious assault on the country's unemployment problem. Labor believes that there is nothing in these bills that can be represented as a fundamental attack on the nation's continuing high unemployment problem. To the contrary, they are likely to create significant barriers to employment for some job seekers, provide cost barriers to employers seeking labour and lead to inefficiency in the operation of the labour market. These bills represent one of the largest and most imprudent privatisations of government services in Australian history. There is no mandate for this legislation. It is yet another example of the government's determination to quietly introduce its 1993 Fightback agenda, hoping that no‐one notices.

Most notably, these bills are further evidence of the government's equivocation on unemployment. National unemployment remains at around the 8.7 per cent level. The decline in the number of long‐term unemployed—experienced under Labor's programs—has ceased. Long‐term unemployment is beginning to rise again. The government's 1996 budget reduced employment assistance, with $1.8 billion cut from labour market programs designed to help the unemployed. The 1997 budget further rations assistance. The government has repeatedly refused to set any target for reducing unemployment in this country. Now it quietly seeks to remove the legislative objective of full employment.
The current act states as its aim:
to promote full employment by providing employment services that are free of charge to job seekers.

Nowhere in this coalition government's bill will you find that or any other commitment to full employment. This is not a drafting oversight. It is a deliberate omission. Full employment is not an objective of this coalition government.

While we are asked to trust the minister on much of the detail of the scheme, the consequences of failure will cost Australia dearly. Re‐establishing the infrastructure of employment services abolished by this bill will be a mammoth and costly task. In the meantime, who will salvage the lives of the long‐term unemployed, abandoned by virtue of these decisions?

Labor will be proposing amendments to these bills that, if passed, will establish a model of employment service provision different in a number of fundamental respects from that proposed by the government. The opposition believes that, if a market for employment assistance is to be created, the parliament must ensure that the rights of the unemployed to access services and assistance are properly protected. The government cannot walk away from the provision of basic employment services to those in need. Maintenance of this essential service is in the community's interest. Under the Labor model, existing public services will be maintained alongside the competitive model proposed for more intensive employment assistance.

Our amendments in no way interfere with the government's intention to establish a competitive market for employment assist ance, despite our serious reservations about the focus and priorities that will create. The government has not sought nor received a mandate to abolish free universal access to employment exchange services. They have not established the case for abandoning that most basic of community service obligations. It is a sad indictment of the government that it simultaneously seeks to make access to a tax break universal while denying unemployed persons access to employment services.

The lack of a guarantee that labour exchange services will be provided free of charge to all job seekers is the major omission in these bills. Labor believes that universal access to labour exchange services is fundamental to a society purporting to provide equality of opportunity to all of its citizens. Since 1946 the Commonwealth Employment Service has provided a free service to fill vacancies and assist all Australians seeking employment. The CES has been the embodiment of Australia's obligation under ILO Convention No. 88, article 1, which requires the maintenance of a free public employment service. This provision of basic labour exchange services by the CES has ensured a national employment market accessible to all, regardless of their locality or personal wealth.

Facilitating free access by employers to people seeking employment and free access to available vacancies by job seekers forms part of the government's basic community obligations. What the government is in fact doing is attempting to introduce a fee‐for‐service regime for employment exchange services in this country.

They do this in part by limiting those who in future will be eligible to access free labour exchange services. Approximately 400,000 job seekers currently registered with the CES will no longer be able to access free, publicly funded labour exchange services. Eligible job seekers—which is the minister's new phrase—will be limited by ministerial directive to recipients of unemployment allowances or other forms of income support, young people aged 15 to 20 not in receipt of income support and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participants in CDEP.

Those new restrictions will impact most heavily on women with working spouses, on newly arrived migrants, on part-time workers seeking full-time work, on people wishing to change jobs and, of course, on those recently retrenched. These people will be forced to make their own arrangements in a new market where EPEs will be paid a fee for placing publicly subsidised clients into vacancies. Clearly, for a non‐subsidised client to be considered for a vacancy by a profit driven EPE, they will need to pay a matching or greater fee. Otherwise there would be no incentive for the EPE to refer the non-subsidised client to an employer.

The government's proposal to permit closed vacancies effectively allows the EPE to own a job vacancy. Commercial realities dictate that EPEs will seek to maintain control of their vacancies and fill them with their own subsidised clients, or those prepared and able to pay a similar or better fee. The government's new labour exchange services market will require non-subsidised clients, currently one‐third of people registered as seeking work, to pay a minimum fee of $250 to a private service provider for the right to simply access job vacancies. Instead of accessing free labour exchange services, those job seekers will have to pay an up-front fee to access the services of an EPE, and in this regime EPEs will effectively control job vacancies and referrals to employers.

This bill effectively erects new barriers for unemployed people in their effort to gain employment. Employers too will be forced for the first time to pay for job screening and job matching services currently performed free by the CES. Businesses will be slugged with this extra cost even if they are seeking seasonal or casual workers.

There is also a risk that segmentation of the labour market will take place through EPEs hoarding vacancies in specialist regional or industry markets. It is likely that EPEs will specialise in particular industries, regions and occupations. If an EPE specialises in a particular industry and a job seeker wishes to enter another industry, there may be no other local EPE with appropriate skills and vacancies. These inefficiencies in the government's model encourage labour market segmentation and immobility between occupations, industries and regions. The difficulties accessing jobs between these segmented labour markets will work against efficiency and increase unemployment.

BREAK.PARA: Rural and regional Australia is likely to suffer further disadvantage as a result of these proposals. The opposition is particularly concerned at the inadequacy of the government's explanation as to how its model will service regions that cannot support a competitive market. Even the government does not deny that higher costs required to deliver services and the absence of employment prospects may mean that some regions cannot be regarded as viable for outcomes based funding. Ministerial reassurances that the PEPE may be directed as a last resort to fill the gaps provide little comfort.

Doubts about the provision of services to rural and regional Australia are reinforced by the government itself in its Budget Employment: Questions and Answers booklet. The booklet poses this question:
Will the new arrangements meet the needs of rural and regional Australia for employment services?
The answer is illuminating. This is the answer by the government:
The legislation does not address the issue of distribution of employment services across Australia . . .

Exactly! That, Senators, is but one of the fundamental flaws in this proposal. It is, however, the only one that the government has had the courage to acknowledge. Unemployed people in rural and regional Australia should receive access to publicly funded, high quality employment services as of right. If anything, extra resources should be directed to address their additional disadvantage. The government's model fails to address those needs.

For all these reasons the opposition will be moving amendments, with the Democrats, guaranteeing that all job seekers have a right to free and universal labour exchange services. These amendments are essential to ensure that the basic community service obligations of the government are not abrogated and that inequalities experienced by unemployed people are not exacerbated.

A further major omission in the legislation is the failure of the government to establish the functions and role of the PEPE within the bill. Despite earlier assurances by the minister, the legislation does not even contain a reference to the public provider. The only reference to the involvement of a PEPE is in the revised ministerial statement, to the effect that a public corporation will be established. We are naturally suspicious that, in establishing the legislative framework for the supposedly competitively neutral market, the government makes no mention at all of the role of the public provider.

We will be moving amendments to establish the PEPE and allocate it appropriate functions. The amendments establish the PEPE as a statutory authority—a far more appropriate vehicle for the provision of community service obligations than the company proposed by the government.

Without these amendments, the parliament will effectively remove any obligation on the government to provide services to the unemployed. To place total faith in the as yet untested private market is, in my view, irresponsible. The market is totally funded by public money. A public provider can provide stability and act as a benchmark for best practice in the new market. In moving to this more competitive market, in what even the government describes as a radical move, the community is entitled to the protection of an ongoing statutory public provider.

The opposition also has concerns that the nature of the corporation means that the role of the public provider could be downgraded, or even abolished, without reference to parliament. To leave any commitment to services for the unemployed to the vagaries of the success or failure of a private corporation in the marketplace would be a total abrogation of our responsibilities as members of this parliament.

The government's proposals fail the test of prudence. By enshrining PEPE and its role and function within the legislation, the parliament will safeguard access to employment services to people in rural Australia and other areas which may not be serviced by private providers. It will also assist to reduce the problems of market segmentation inherent in the government's proposal.

The government's assertion that our ILO and community service obligations are met by the most rudimentary facilities to be provided at the Commonwealth services delivery agency is unsustainable and, quite frankly, insulting. There is clearly a role for the experience, skills and talents of the former CES staff to be used in providing services to the unemployed. They are best placed to offer employment assistance. We are extremely concerned at reports of ministerial pressure to limit the size of the market that the PEPE can gain. The ideological pursuits of this government should not lay to waste the public investment in those services. The legislation must ensure that investment and resources are retained.

It is ironic that the first and only certain impact of these government `reforms' is the loss of between 3,000 and 6,000 jobs in the public sector. The amendments we will move, if successful, may help reduce that unfortunate, self-defeating impact. Consistent with our position on the agency bill, the opposition will be supporting the maintenance of public service terms and conditions for those employees moving to the PEPE.

The opposition has been impressed by the range of concerns of community groups and providers about how the market will operate in practice and whether or not it will deliver the quality of service, the equity and the value for money the government claims. The bill purports to establish a competitively neutral market for the allocation of public funding of services to selected unemployed persons, but even the government concedes that the market is a new one and will contain many imperfections.

The fixed price tender system will be used initially with competitive price tendering in future rounds. Profit making, not for profit organisations and the PEPE will allegedly compete on equal terms in that market. It is not at all clear to the opposition as to how this is all to be achieved but, again, we are simply required to trust the government and leave the detail to them.

It has been argued that the strength of these proposals is in their shift from a focus on processes to one more directed at outcomes. The present system can benefit from a greater emphasis on individual needs, but this proposal goes too far. It focuses solely on easily measured outcomes achieved by whatever means. The pressure will be on the providers to meet outcomes rather than on the quality of an outcome. The problems of the labour market, the unemployed and the long-term unemployed are far more complex than that. They are people, not commodities.

Those with experience in this field fear the emergence of a range of different problems. They question whether the profit motive will interfere with the provision of the best possible services to the unemployed. They question whether the process will encourage providers to deal with the least disadvantaged clients at the cost of those most in need. They question whether the focus on placement outcomes will militate against the provision of training and support to ensure sustained employment.

Labor believes that optimal outcomes for the job seeker are most likely where the interests of the job seeker are paramount. With no higher interest than the profit available, it is highly likely that outcomes will be characterised by less secure, lower quality, lower skilled employment. Quality of outcome—that is, long-term, sustainable employment—is no longer an objective. The government's proposal, in our view, shifts the balance too far to an outcome based approach. The opposition has a range of concerns regarding the regime controlling EPEs. As with so many issues arising from this bill, the lack of detail is a concern.

Over $1 billion of public funds are to be placed at the disposal of private providers. The community and the parliament must be satisfied that these funds are expended in an accountable manner effectively and that they provide value for money. The parliament must ensure that EPEs provide appropriate services of a high quality to job seekers. We must ensure that these clients receive the absolutely highest standard of service possible in the new market.

We will be seeking to ensure that sufficient accountability measures are put in place to protect the massive public investment in EPEs and the service they provide to clients. The opposition will also be seeking assurances from the minister that the standards of privacy, rights to freedom of information, appeal rights, et cetera, are not diminished in any way by virtue of the privatisation of employment services.

In conclusion, the Labor Party cannot support the bill in its current form. So much of the government's proposed model for employment services is a reflection of conservative ideology rather than of sound public policy. That ideology is sought to be implemented with minimal community debate and pursued without community support and without minimal prudent safeguards of the public interest.

The exclusion of 400,000 Australians from access to basic public labour exchange services is a repudiation of our ILO commitments and a betrayal of those who are the most vulnerable in our society. It is a callous and discriminatory measure. The government has offered no adequate explanation for its failure to establish the public employment service provider in the legislation. One can only conclude that it is not committed to the provision of public employment services in the long term.

The changes contained in the move to a competitive market for employment assistance are sufficient to make even the most foolhardy cautious. To adopt these measures without the safeguards proposed by Labor and the Democrats would be a disgraceful abrogation of a basic tenet of civilised societies. It is incredible that such a measure is being proposed at a time of persistent high unemployment. The government has completely failed to establish the case for removing and reducing services to the unemployed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment is the most serious issue facing our nation. These bills that we are considering today, in conjunction with the previously considered Commonwealth Ser vices Delivery Agency Bill, set up the statutory framework for the implementation of the reforms to employment services which this government outlined in its budget last year. So this is part of this government's response to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes which these bills facilitate are the most far-reaching changes to employment placement services since the CES was established in 1946. The abolition of the CES and the establishment of a new competitively neutral—and I wish that we had a way for Hansard to record that when I say `competitively neutral', I mean it to be in inverted commas—labour market placement service will effectively take Australia from a system where the government has played an active role in the provision of employment services to one where it will take a hands‐off approach.

I say I wish I could always acknowledge the quotation marks, because I do not accept the way the government uses this jargon. So I am going to ask that when I use, `in the name of competition policy', `in the name of privatisation', `in the name of rationing of funds', and `in the name of corporatisation, we are making these changes', those terms be taken as being in inverted commas. These are the jargon and the cornerstones of the economic rationalist approach which has dominated economic debate in this country for well over a decade now.

In the new `competitive environment' public employment agencies—or PEPEs—will compete with private employment agencies—or EPEs—for employment vacancies and for job seekers. Payment for EPEs and PEPEs will be primarily on an outcomes basis. In other words, I agree with the comments that this puts process onto a more important level than people, the receivers of the service.

Although the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) says that these bills are just an extension of Labor's Working Nation program, this model is without precedent in the Western world and it will take Australia further towards free market employment assistance and job placement services than any country has ever gone before.

BREAK.PARA: We need to be very clear about this. This makes these reforms a huge social experiment which may or may not produce positive results. That is why we have been spending a lot of time seeking adequate safeguards, including a strong public provider. We believe that there is still an important role for government in employment service provision.

I want to make one point clear: the Democrats are not afraid of change; we are not afraid of radical change. But we do believe that the most likely effects of change need to be considered and understood very clearly before they are passed into law. That is why we believe it is important to fill in the nitty‐gritty details of how this will work out there in the real world before asking parliament to give it the big tick, as is often the case here, because hundreds of thousands of Australians stand to be affected by these changes.

We have a number of problems with this legislation. We have a number of concerns about the nature of the broader changes which are being proposed. We are concerned at the lack of detail which these bills contain, particularly on the corporatised public provider. As is the case with many other incredibly important and contentious pieces of legislation, I am certain that many Australians who will be affected by this do not yet realise the magnitude of these changes. I am also sure that many Australians currently using the services of the CES do not yet realise that their access to many of the services they have been accustomed to is about to be curtailed.

It is true that, while all Australians will still have access to self‐help facilities at the new one‐stop shop, the really important qualifier is that only those who are in receipt of unemployment benefits or other forms of qualifying government support—such as young people aged 15 to 20 years who are registered as unemployed with a CSDA and not in full‐time education; Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander participants in community development employment projects; or people who are placed in an entry level training vacancy—will still have access to additional forms of employment assistance.

On the other hand, people who have working partners, part‐time workers looking for more work, workers looking for alternative employment, school and university students looking for part‐time work, and anyone looking for work but not claiming DSS allowances will not be really be able to access these additional services. Surely, at a time of the increasing casualisation of the work force when so many Australians are forced to work fewer hours—not by choice but because that is all the work they can find—and surely when they have a right to find more work, they should not be denied access to the assistance to make this possible.

I will be very interested to hear the minister explain how the government thinks people who are no longer eligible for assistance will find a job once these changes are enforced. I know that she says that the EPEs are going to have this pool of other people there because it makes sense to them to be able to say to people seeking to use them, `Oh, we've got a huge number of people on our books.' I would like her to convince us that that is really the way it is going to happen and why that gives people sufficient protection.

I would also be very interested to hear exactly what effect the government thinks this set of changes will have on the participation rate of women and on part‐time workers. The Democrats believe that everyone should continue to have access to free labour exchange services. We too want to ensure that Australians living in rural and remote areas continue to have access to a similar range of services to those of their urban counterparts.

The lack of detail which surrounds the way the EPEs will operate and the services they will provide is also a matter about which we are deeply concerned. Precisely who will be able to apply to become an EPE? What services will these organisations provide? How will they be accredited? We look forward to hearing the detail.

While the Democrats acknowledge that the government has now supplied some of the details regarding the way EPEs will operate in its exposure draft on tenders, there are still many aspects surrounding the operations of EPEs that we are concerned about.

One of the major issues is how these organisations will be accredited. I just think that this is too important to take the details on trust. We did not do that with a Labor government and we do not think it is right to do it with a coalition government. It is not good enough to come and fill in the really important detail afterwards. Unless there is a rigorous system of accreditation, monitoring and evaluation, there will be too much room for unscrupulous EPEs to rort the system and exploit unemployed Australians.
One witness to the committee hearing on this bill suggested that the process of determining how to rort the system is already well under way, with a:

. . . burgeoning industry out there in terms of people coming up with all sorts of possible scams they could operate with a view to doing these sorts of things. The sorts of things that are being bandied around include under‐the‐table payments to personnel officers in companies to get them to agree to take your person rather than over the table. Others include trading in cases of wine and all sorts of other things.

ACOSS has already seen this happen. There also seems to be a great deal of scope for fly‐by‐night shonks to set up as EPEs for no other reason than to feather their own nests. It is a good little business opportunity for a short time.

As far as we can see, there is nothing in this legislation to prevent unscrupulous operators from registering as EPEs—it might be possible to meet the accreditation standards and still be totally unscrupulous—signing up a number of job seekers in order to get the first outcome payments and then promptly going out of business. Other possibilities which have been raised include EPEs paying corporations to give them job vacancies, EPEs minimising the level of training they offer and EPEs `creaming' off the job seekers most likely to get a job.

So under these bills we are being asked to implement, the EPEs will have a great deal of power, yet we have no assurance they are going to deliver real employment outcomes. If these new EPEs do fail to deliver, the result will be that some of the most vulnerable members of our society will be in a worse situation than they are now because there will be nowhere left to go.

We can expect the minister to say that the CES has not been performing and we can expect her to point out its outcomes compared with some private agencies, but at least there is a CES to go to for those who have no other options. Do you think Drake wants to deal with the kinds of people who go to the CES as a last resort?

There will be no CES to pick up the pieces because the CES, once it becomes the new PEPE, will be significantly pared back in terms of its staff and its services to make it more `competitive', as the jargon goes. So there is a lot riding on the success or failure of the measures we are considering today. I do not think it is possible to overemphasise the importance of monitoring, evaluating and even adjusting some of these reforms along the way.

We do not believe that DEETYA is the appropriate body to carry out this monitoring and evaluation. While we recognise that DEETYA will be the purchaser as opposed to the provider of employment services, we think there will still be some conflict of interest with DEETYA carrying out these additional tasks. We think an independent watchdog council established along the lines of a reformed ESRA would be in a much better position to carry out the oversight and evaluation of employment placement services and these reforms generally. We intend to move an amendment to that effect.

One of the other more controversial aspects of these reforms is that labour market assistance will be restricted to people the department feels will benefit most from assistance and that assistance will be rationed to 12 months. So many concerns have been raised about this that I could not summarise them all in the time left today, but I will put on the record some of the main areas of concern. They are the lack of assistance which will be available to job seekers once they have completed their 12 months intensive employment assistance, the impact this restriction may have on people with disabilities and the possibility that job seekers who are not eligible for additional employment assistance will end up on some kind of job scrap heap.

While the government has said that the answer to this is the community support programs to help those people who are deemed not to be eligible for the 12 months of intensive assistance, again this is taken on trust. We have heard too few details about how these programs will work.

The Democrats support community support programs which assist unemployed people with literacy and numeracy problems, with drug and alcohol rehabilitation and with personal counselling and housing placement, but we do not support the kind of either/or approach this government has adopted on this particular issue. We think community support programs should be available to all job seekers in addition to other forms of employment assistance.

Finally, there is widespread concern among those experienced in working with unemployed people that EPEs will `cream off' job seekers who will be easiest to place and neglect those who pose more of a challenge. I think it is important to note that some of the bigger EPEs would be able to earn quite a decent income just by collecting first outcome payments for job seekers who register with them and collecting second outcome payments for those job seekers they can easily place in work.

Many of these concerns that have been raised by Senator Chris Evans and me are as yet unproven one way or the other. But in trying to understand how these changes can work, we have spoken to those who have the experience of working with unemployed people and they share our concern about the lack of detail.

These reforms are, yet again, about ideology—the obsession with all things private, the belief that private is always better than public and the belief that, whatever you do, you do not do anything that would give public providers any more resources than the competing private providers. I do not deny that private delivery of some services is better, and it may even be better in this particular area. As I say, this is a big social experiment. We do not know what will happen and that is why we must insist on a proper monitoring and evaluation process. We will be moving—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to do something; you can't stick with the old.

—I will stick with the old if it is proven. I do not abandon really important concepts like community service obligations and public interest just because you want something new. There are some traditions in life and some principles which stand the test of time and fashion, and economic rationalism and abandoning all things public is not what the Democrats are about.

BREAK.PARA: , We will be moving several amendments to these bills. We will be supporting the ALP amendments that we have discussed as the majority of them duplicate those which we were planning to move. We have an open mind on a couple of matters, and we are happy to listen to the minister's explanations.

We have already been happy to sit down and talk to the minister about the amendments. We understand the concerns, but we have been unable to reach significant common ground on the major thrust of these bills because we do not accept the privatisation of employment services without strong and appropriate safeguards.

We have addressed the technical difficulties of our amendments, which were pointed out to us by the department. I think the minister has to acknowledge that we have listened and that we have gone away and made some changes. But, in the end, we are coming from completely different philosophical perspectives.

As jobs and job seekers become commodities in this brave new world, we must not forget the importance of monitoring the human cost of these reforms. As I said by way of interjection earlier, we must not abandon our commitment to community service obligations and the public interest. We must resist, in my view, corporatising the entire community in which we live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear from the outset that the Australian Greens oppose the employment services reform legislation. I hope that the Labor Party and, indeed, the Australian Democrats will oppose the legislation as well. I do not have the faith—a residual faith at that—that the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) has that there may be a good side to the operations of private operators in the field of job placement. If it were established that that is the case, then let us go in that direction. But it has not been established.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have in this country is a Commonwealth Employment Service which is available to Australians right around the nation and which is an extension of the government obligation to those nearly one in 10 people seeking jobs in this country who cannot get a job—not because they are not up to it but because the jobs do not exist. Not even Maggie Thatcher privatised employment services.

What are we doing in here with this idea from the right field, unheralded? We are making a social experimentation with the unemployed people in Australia. The whole idea is a horrible one. It will be particularly horrible for those people in this country who are already disillusioned and are despairing about their future because they cannot get a job because the job does not exist for them.

If there is one responsibility we as parliamentarians have to accept it is to move towards creating the jobs which are going to give those people hope again. You do not do that by privatising the national obligation to a national employment service. That is simply fiddling—a social experimentation—with people. We are not taking the risk. It is a risk in respect of the hundreds of thousands of unemployed people around this country, not least of which is the one in three young people in my home state of Tasmania who cannot get a job because the job does not exist.

It is not their fault; it is the fault of the way our society is structured in this age of economic rationalism. It has affected the long-term unemployed in this country, who are of all ages and most of whom are skilled and have gone through a long educative process skilling themselves for a job which no longer exists in this fast changing society. I submit that this process, instead of putting public funds into helping reskill those people, will put them into the pockets of private so-called job providing alternatives to the Commonwealth employment services.

To boot, thousands of people who are now in jobs with the Commonwealth employment services around this country are going to lose their jobs on the altar of social experimentation by the economic fundamentalists who sit opposite. The Greens will not have a bar of it.

It has been a pretty bad week in Australian politics. We had the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to apologise on behalf of the nation to those who have suffered as a result of the abhorrent stolen generations episode. In just the last couple of days, we had the government, not least the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), abrogate its responsibility to the nation's environment by handing its licensing authority over to the miners and the loggers and, therefore, its ability to protect the nation's prime environment. Here we are today handing across to a profit‐seeking sector of the community a government obligation to provide not just employment services but also skilling services for those people who are unemployed in this country.

The Greens have looked at the figures and, on the best estimates we can get, this measure will mean that 151,000 long‐term unemployed people in this country will be left on the scrap heap. They are the people who will have no reskilling programs available to them. They will have no particular avenue for a return into a job and the fulfilment and the sense of self‐worth that comes with that.

There are 246,000 people in Australia who have been unemployed for 12 months or more as of this month. It is expected that the government's privatised program will help 78,000 of them. A further 10,000 young people will be forced onto the mandatory, compulsory work for the dole scheme of Senator Vanstone and Senator Newman, and 6,375 are participating in community support program placements. That leaves 151,600 long‐term unemployed people who have not got anything. What they do know is that the jobs are not there. What they do know is that they cannot create those jobs. It is ultimately a vindictive way of dealing, not only with those young people who are least able to get a job and have for the longest period of time had to deal with the disheartenment and disillusionment of not getting a job, but it is going to selectively pick regional areas of Australia—the pockets of highest unemployment. If you look at the situation in New York City, there are some 26,000 people street cleaning and fixing up parks and gardens on pitiable wages through compulsory work for the dole schemes replacing people who used to get proper wages and conditions in those very jobs.

It will end up not only affecting those people and further disillusioning them—because it is not going to skill them for a job that they want to get fulfilment out of further down the line—but it is also going to knock out of a properly waged and conditioned job people who would otherwise have been in full‐time employment.

I will be moving an amendment to ensure that these privatised for profit employment agencies, who are now going to replace the Commonwealth Employment Service, are not simply able to get off their books the people they dislike and say, `We'll transfer you across to a compulsory work for the dole scheme, because that is in the interests of us making money.' It is social experimentation and it is ultimately going to abuse those people least able to defend themselves and who already feel bad enough about not having a job.
