BREAK.PARA: There was a great deal of concern about the way the legislation was rushed through in 1995, about what the potential implications were and about whether we, as a country, were the least bit prepared for what we were jumping into. We claimed at the time that we were not. Two years on it really is time to look at this—at where we are going, how far we have got, what the implications for people are and what they could be by next year, when the bill crunches in. In the not too distant future, I intend to propose a full review of the 1995 competition policy legislation.

It is a bit rich for the Labor Party to come in now and say, `Isn't it dreadful how this is being implemented?' Yes, it is dreadful. But it is also the policy that was put in in 1995 in relation to competition policy. It did not direct that labour market programs should be privatised, but it basically said that state, federal and local services would go along in that direction, unless specifically exempted. I believe it is time we looked at the bill that was pushed through here in 1995. It is time we looked at the human, social and environmental implications—and any other implications—of what the two major parties in this chamber signed up to in 1995.

There is another major issue in relation to perceptions here. What we see now is that the unemployed are becoming the victims of the theatre of politics. We know that in 1993 the Greens pointed out that there was a big hole of around $5 billion in the budget calculations. This hole, we pointed out, belonged to the labour market programs. In 1994, up came the $5 billion in the form of the Working Nation program. It got recycled, it came up by way of Working Nation and was proclaimed as a big new spending package. It was not a big new spending package. The only people who noticed that it was pulled out of the budget in 1993 were the Greens. Some other people caught on later, but they forgot it over time. So we had a `big new spending package', which never was a big new spending package. It was a transfer of programs, it was a revitalisation but it was not a big new spending package.

Having produced the theatre of the big new spending package, we then had the theatre of the opposition saying, `You have spent big with $5 billion.' Then we had, `We've spent big', `You've spent too much', across the chamber. Having built on the politics of perception and the theatre of politics, the now opposition is in no position to say, `If you are pulling billions of dollars out of this program, it never was a new spending program.' They cannot do that, because they always said it was a big new spending program.

What we have now, in the form of the government's new program for the work for your poverty scheme, is an ideologically driven program. It is not yet required under competition policy, but by 1998 it may well be. It is driven by the fact that private must be good and public or community must be bad. In the case of not for profit organisations, you have incentives. People work there because they believe they are doing the right thing. They believe in serving the community.

Whether it is in an accountable area such as the provision of government services or it is in the area of the provision of community services in terms of employment programs and so on that are run by a whole range of agencies in the community, there is an incentive within those groups to provide that service for the community. They are being pitted against the private for profit sector, and it does not take much to work out that, if one is competing with the other at the same price, one has a profit margin and the other is putting their profit back into the community. Therefore, it would seem that we will be getting less value from the private sector than we may well be getting from the community sector. The motivations would need to be checked.

The actual running of the program becomes extremely difficult to monitor to make sure that we are not going to get the inevitable creaming off of the system which comes when you have got a for‐profit sector which has an incentive to place and is provided with this great little excuse, which is already sorted out, in relation to those people who are less likely or are unlikely to find employment.

I really think the `capacity to benefit' test is an extraordinary provision because it talks about people personally but it also indicates that certain parts of Australia may be classified as basket cases. We will get enclaves of disadvantage and we will get enclaves of lack of assistance within Australia. I just wonder how the government will come in then and justify what they are going to be doing in relation to those people who fall out of their category who are then labelled and stigmatised. We are going back decades in relation to the basic human dignity of people.

I think it is similar to the Alan Jones approach to social justice. I know that in a promo to one of his programs you had an unemployed person, just after the budget was announced, saying, `Look, I just want to talk about the issue of money available to unemployed people. I have been unemployed for six years.' The response was something like, `Oh well, you are just a layabout. It is your fault.' That is the approach that has been taken by the government. That is the approach we have had on many occasions from Senator Newman: `We would like to trust these people but, gosh, there are people who are cheats.'

Therefore we get the impression that it is the fault of the unemployed to be unemployed, that it is the fault of the long‐term unemployed that there are problems as to why they cannot get a job. They are assumed to be guilty unless they can somehow or other prove themselves to be innocent. People have approached my office who have been summarily taken off their unemployment benefit, for a technicality sometimes, and frequently for mistakes of the system, and they then have the responsibility of proving that the system has treated them badly. It is like a huge fine. We would never do this to business. Can you imagine fining someone who has got nothing the equivalent of $500? It is outrageous. But we are doing that because it is part of the scapegoat politics which is popular at the moment.

We do need to look at the future, we need to look at where this country is going and we need to look at the fact that this policy is pushing for a more and more divided Australia. The poverty trap has been set and the ability of people to work out of the poverty trap is in question. I just wonder whether in the future we will move even further, to forced labour or indentured labour. That is what it is likely to be.

We are already finding in the last couple of years in Western Australia that the ability of people to opt for community service for minor offences rather than for fines they cannot pay has been removed in a number of instances. One wonders whether that was a sort of preparation for a work for the dole scheme. Now if you are unemployed you will be punished—it is not optional; you will be punished—by being put into what somebody, perhaps a private company, thinks is your correct and appropriate punishment. So, instead of people being able to do community service in many instances, say, in the state systems, there are some categories of people who can no longer access community service, and now that is the punishment, the punishment for being unemployed.

Sure, there are people who are unemployed, and certainly a lot of young people, who would like the opportunity of getting meaningful work experience, but that is not the same. We have seen the government pull out the money from the LEAP scheme and we have seen it go to a scheme called Green Corps, which is much less in monetary terms, much less in numbers, and often means that people, instead of being involved in something that they think is worth while and the community thinks is worth while, end up being unwilling participants in something they do not understand. It is not all willing people; it is often people who really feel that they have been targeted for being bad, targeted for being unemployed.

I do not think this is the kind of Australia I would like to live in and I think it is time that people understand where the decisions are coming from and take action. One of those actions perhaps is to call for a major review of competition policy, a major review of the direction we are going in, which sees that `Economic fundamentalism rules—okay?' in Australia—no matter what the social cost, no matter what other costs are involved, no matter what the outcomes are, as long as it is ideologically driven.

I would like to think that all people in this chamber could believe that it is time after two years to review competition policy. I do not think anybody in a major party can pretend that their parties were not fully a part of that decision. It was a policy that was put forward by the Labor Party and it was a policy that was fully supported by the then opposition, and there was almost no debate. Of course, the people who were concerned included the local government associations, who are still vitally concerned about the outcomes, especially in rural and regional Australia but not solely in those areas. People are finding out that their decisions are being overridden now—or potentially will be in the future—because their rules or their legislation somehow do not conform to a very odd idea of what is competition.

And why should they? There are other values in this society, and democracy demands that people have the ability to be represented for values other than corporate profit. But, funnily enough, that is not what is happening at the moment. So, before we go too far down this track, it is time for a very urgent review of where we are going in this country and what the outcomes are.

So in the not too distant future honourable senators can expect me to be putting forward a proposal for a two‐yearly review of competition policy. I hope that those people from the Labor Party who are concerned about how, both at a federal level and at the state and territory levels, competition policy is currently being implemented will participate fully in that debate, because I know there are many people in the community who are ready and more than willing to come forward and give their evidence about the implications of what has gone on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a shame that Senator McGauran is not here because, in an earlier interchange with Senator Kernot as to the justification for this employment services bill, his response was, `We have to try something new.' I would like to remind the chamber of the target of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) with regard to unemployment—that is, eight per cent by June 1998. That means that this government is aiming for a 0.7 per cent cut after 2½ years in office. So it is no wonder that Senator McGauran says that we have to try something new.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is the political equivalent of kicking the cat. It is the political equivalent of scapegoating the CES because of the appalling record this government has in relation to unemployment. Unemployment has gone up in the last 18 months but, instead of doing anything fundamental about that, this government is choosing to kick the cat, to dismantle the CES and blame those workers in the CES for its appalling record and its appalling outcome.

This legislation before us goes by the misnomer `reform'—Reform of Employment Services Bill. This bill is not about reform. Reform implies something positive, improvement, righting wrongs, making things better. There is no reform in this bill. There is a dismantling, a taking apart, an annihilation, of a system that has been in existence for in excess of 50 years.

The title of the bill uses the words `employment services', another absolute misnomer. The kindest thing you could call it is a disservice in terms of the outcomes that it is going to deliver to the Australian people. The legislation effectively removes services for the unemployed and it abandons them in their hundreds of thousands.

As Senator O'Brien has already pointed out, this government has no mandate for this legislation. The government did not announce plans to abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service in its 1996 election campaign. In fact, as has been pointed out, in correspondence to the CPSU, the government promised to support the CES as a public employment service. When the now government announced in 1993 its intention to `privatise or contract out' most of the job placement activities at the CES, what happened in that 1993 election? You did not get in. The now government did not get in. That policy, along with a whole range of other policies, received a resounding `no' from the people of Australia. So here we go again. It is the Fightback agenda by the back the backdoor with no mandate.

Here is a blatant attempt to meet the budget bottom line, again, at the expense of those least able to afford it—that is, the unemployed of Australia. As the Age reported on Monday, 5 May, the Treasurer has had to concede that his employment strategies have not worked and his jobless target of 8.5 per cent will not be met.

Unlike the Treasurer, Labor keeps its promises to the unemployed of the country. At the time of the 1993 election, Labor promised to create half a million jobs over three years. Not only did we achieve that target; we exceeded it. We created 714,000 jobs in less than three years. We did this at the same time as increasing participation in the work force by Australian women. Under this government, women are leaving the work force in droves. In the month of March, 50,000 women left the work force or stopped looking for work—the worst fall in the participation rate of women since September 1979.

We created jobs without abandoning disadvantaged job seekers. We did it through Working Nation. We focused on active market assistance and education and training. We believe that every Australian has a capacity to benefit. We focused on disadvantaged job seekers and disadvantaged areas. We provided necessary infrastructure for job seeker training. We developed regional employment strategies. We involved local business and local communities in the decision making, and we were well on the way to five per cent unemployment by the year 2000.

Instead of building on the success of Working Nation, this government has slashed funds to labour market programs—in fact, as everybody knows, over $1.8 billion nationwide. This slashing and burning of labour market programs is being felt disproportionately in regional Australia. Over $40 million has been taken from my home state of Tasmania alone—the state, incidentally, with the highest unemployment rate in Australia and the state, incidentally, that is going to be one of the worst affected by this bill.

This government plans to abolish the CES. The government has the temerity to call this reform. Instead of publicly funded, universally available employment services, we will now have the employment placement enterprises, EPEs—the profit driven employment placement enterprises. The CES was established to match people to jobs. Over time, the role expanded to actively assisting the long-term unemployed and those disadvantaged in the job market. Profit has never been a motive.

While we are talking about profit, let us talk about those community groups who work tirelessly for no profit. How will they fare in being able to set up an EPE? The reality is that there is no guarantee that community groups which wish to become EPEs will be able to do so. There is every likelihood that they will find it impossible to compete with large private enterprises with considerable capital and existing infrastructure available to them.

Not‐for‐profit organisations do not have the capacity to compete with large groups like Benson and Drake International. The cost of public relations and general running expenses is huge. There is every likelihood that large cartels will dominate the employment market. It does not sound much like competition, does it? It does not sound much like competition because it is not going to be much like competition.

There are many reasons why the whole issue of contracting out such a vital public service should be questioned. The issue of public accountability lies at the very heart of this bill. As the Public Research Centre of the University of New South Wales said to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee, government services have `complex and multiple objectives'. The research points to the ever present risk of corruption in contracting processes. The centre's submission went on to say:

The contracting process can diminish transparency and public accountability in public administration and service provision through `commercial in confidence' declarations and restrictions on freedom of information provisions.

Under the changes proposed in this bill, the power of the government to scrutinise the activities of its services to the unemployed is severely diminished. In answer to my question in this chamber with regard to abuse of confidential information by former departmental officers in Tasmania who wished to set up an EPE, Minister Vanstone could only reply that there were reports that the problem was widespread and that she would have a look at it.

This evidence of the potential for corruption is merely the tip of the iceberg. I repeat: EPEs will be profit making ventures to which vital social services will be contracted out. You cannot contract out responsibility. EPEs will receive a fee for placing a client in employment. People who need intensive help and training will be, as has been pointed out by a number of senators, less attractive to the EPE than those who can find work quickly and return a fast profit to the EPE.

With no fee, the CES helps anyone who wants help to find a job. Under the new regime, job seekers will receive help to find work only if they are in receipt of benefit or fit specific categories. Anyone else will go onto the scrap heap or will have to pay a fee for service. Through the CES, people have access to a wide range of assistance: training, wage subsidies, even assistance to move to another location if necessary in relation to the search for work.

The EPE will receive some money up front to place a person in employment. How much of that fee will be spent on the job seeker is the decision of the EPE—that is, after the salaries, rent, insurance, electricity, and telephone costs and so on are taken out. The waste through duplication of services and resources defies any sense at all; it defies logic.

Under the CES, a job seeker receives help for as long as necessary to overcome any barrier to employment or until a person returns to education or, hopefully, gets a job. If the job is lost within 13 weeks, that person can return to the level of assistance they were receiving before they got the job.

EPEs have 12 months to find a person a job. In some circumstances, that continue for a further six months. But if at the end of 12 months a person has no job they lose the right to get intensive employment assistance. The only way a person can get further assistance is to find a job by themselves and, if they lose the job, they need to reapply for assistance.

What of the safeguards? Under this legislation the job seeker cannot change EPEs if he or she is dissatisfied or if the EPE makes unreasonable demands of them—like moving to a different area, for example, away from infrastructure, family, whatever—and then threatens them with a breach if they do not comply.

The CES is free. The staff are trained, experienced and skilled public servants. Training, counselling, access to phones, fax and photocopier—all that sort of thing—are free. The EPE can and will charge for anything over and above the basic service for people referred by the agency. People who are not referred can be charged for even the most basic service. So we will be moving away from a publicly funded service for the unemployed to private concerns driven by the profit motive.

The government is flying in the face of reports which demonstrate that the CES has been vital in the fight to put all unemployed Australians back into work. The client surveys report National survey of employer satisfaction, published by DEETYA stated that:
85% of employers were satisfied with the services provided by the CES.

Why change that? It does not make any sense. If it is working, why change it? Despite this, this government would have us all believe that this move to a market for employment services is an improvement. ACOSS said in their submission to the Senate hearing:

This is a very risky experiment for unemployed people, for whom the labour market has rarely delivered a fair outcome. This market failure provides a powerful case for government intervention in the labour market to ensure that the most disadvantaged and long-term unemployed people are re-connected with secure employment and can participate fully in society.

This requires the development, over an extensive period of time, of a network of stable, high quality employment assistance providers to provide counselling, training, employment experience, and job referral.

These providers must be encouraged to assist the most disadvantaged unemployed people into stable employment—as distinct from picking the `easiest jobs' or cutting their costs by offering only superficial training and support.
The basis for such a network already exists and it is vital that this is not destroyed in the process of reform.

This so-called reform would not be the subject of so much concern if we could be confident that a mechanism was being put in place to ensure that those people not helped by the EPE would receive assistance from another source. However, as has been pointed out, at no stage have we received an assurance that employment services will be delivered in the regions which have the greatest need.

In my home state of Tasmania we attempted to get some assurance that there would at least be a PEPE based in Tasmania to pick up any market failure in relation to EPEs. We could not get that guarantee. This is a state with the highest unemployment rate, with what is essentially a microcosm of a regional economy, and we could not get that commitment. Earlier assurances from the government led many people to believe that any gaps in the services provided by the EPEs would be covered by another new body, the public placement enterprise—the PEPE. This PEPE is supposed to fill the gaps left by other providers. If a commercial EPE does not set up in a certain remote or rural area, the minister may direct the PEPE to provide services as part of a community service obligation. But the PEPE is to be a company. The establishment and operational parameters of the PEPE are not in the legislation.

There is no guarantee under this legislation in its current form that the PEPE will continue. At any time, for any reason, the government could decide to axe the PEPE. This would leave rural and remote areas without any access to service. In fact, I would go as far as to say that this is precisely what the government is planning to do in the long term—get rid of the PEPE all together and have the private sector running employment services in this country completely.

Incorporating the PEPE has ramifications for service delivery in regional Australia. This legislation gives no assurances that areas of high unemployment or with small or widely dispersed populations will receive an equitable service.

This brings me to the issue of who gets help to find work. People will be divided into three groups—I think as Senator Kernot indicated—in this brave new world. The first group is defined as those who need little or no assistance to find work. They will have access to labour exchange services only. This bill does not provide for basic employment assistance such as self‐help labour exchanges or employment counselling or access to financial assistance with the direct costs of a job search. These services should be a basic minimum.

The second group are identified as those who are needing intensive employment assistance. These are the ones from whom the EPE will make their profit. At least they will get some help, however inferior it may be.

The whole question as to how long a person should receive employment assistance has been a real bugbear for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs under this government. They had to come up with a way to get people off assistance—hence, the 12‐month rule. As evidenced by an internal CES e-mail, limiting access to employment assistance to 12 months provided a convenient way to get people off assistance. One such e-mail concluded by saying:
So you could well say that what we ended up with—
that is, the 12‐month rule—
did not go far enough to allow case managers to move out all the clients they would like to.
But consider that every client affected by any of these new clauses is one more than they could previously exit, and count the blessings. The twelve month rule alone could affect 60,000 clients.

It is not me saying this. I am not saying this. It is the CES workers themselves saying this. They are saying this, not me. The fact is that 60,000 job seekers could lose their entitlement to employment assistance simply because they have not found a job within 12 months. They have few blessings to count.

The third group will not be referred to an EPE, as they are those who will be classified as having `no capacity to benefit' from employment assistance. What a damning term that is—no capacity to benefit. These people will be relegated to the unemployment scrap heap and they will receive no assistance at all. These people, and I will quote again from a CES internal e-mail, include:
. . . violent clients, pregnant clients, Aboriginals in remote locations.
Think about that. The bill is also deficient on the subject of appeal processes for job seekers who are unhappy with the EPE to which they were referred.

The submission from the CPSU raised the concern that 30 per cent of job seekers would effectively be excluded from the appeal process by the requirement that complaints must be in writing. There is no recognition of the fact that many job seekers are functionally illiterate.

What will the government offer young unemployed people instead of labour market programs and the full support of the Commonwealth Employment Service? Work for the dole. There is no sunset clause with regard to work for the dole. This means the government can, without recourse to parliament, force all recipients of unemployment benefits into working for their entitlements. Failure to comply with work for the dole rules will result in loss of benefit. This is a clear attempt to force people off benefits.

There are moral and ethical problems associated with forcing people to work for what has always been considered a right—that is, support while without paid employment. The bill, if passed in the current form, leaves the door open for work for the dole but provides no detail as to how this scheme will operate. There are no details about important issues such as training for the participants, no guarantees that paid jobs will not be lost and no reference to superannuation, workers compensation, occupational health and safety and on and on and on.

The unemployed of this country are not the only ones whose future is put at risk by this bill. What of the staff of the Commonwealth Employment Service? What is their future? We already know that the government wants to dismantle the Australian Public Service. We have already had an admission that public servants can do the same job for differing rates of pay depending on the state of the labour market in the area in which they live. We have already had that admission from the Department of Industrial Relations.

There are between 5,500 and 6,000 people available in the CES to work with the PEPE. However, the PEPE will only need somewhere between 1,800 and 2,500 staff based on business levels. What will happen to the others? What sorts of guarantees do they have? Another internal departmental memo reads:
We need to accept the reality that we will be providing employment for less than 50 per cent of our current staff.
We need to accept that the PEPE does not have responsibility for the employment of CES staff.
It goes on to say:
We will be able to `headhunt' the best staff.
And:
We will not have a Public Service `selection exercise'—if we do the PEPE will be a failure.

Somewhere between 2,500 and 3,000 public servants can join the queue at the labour exchange and get themselves to an EPE under this legislation. Those who retain employment must also retain full Australian Public Service employment conditions. The same conditions must apply to any future PEPE employees. Clearly, this bill has no regard for people. It must be opposed in its current form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mackay said that an essential problem with the Reform of Employment Services Bill 1996 [1997] is the lack of detail. That is correct. The second reading speech said that this legislation purports to affect:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most radical changes to employment services since the establishment of the Commonwealth Employment Service in 1946.
If that is so, surely this chamber needs to know some more detail about how this scheme is to work than is presently available.

For example, at an estimates committee hearing, we were given a booklet entitled Exposure Draft: Tendering conditions and draft contract for employment services. On page 30 of that booklet, the following passage appears:

The Government is preparing to go to tender for a new employment services market. Tenders are to be called for five different kinds of employment services in 29 regions. The tender process will be one of the largest and most complex ever conducted in Australia.

That would seem to mean that the 29 regions which are set out in appendix 3 of the exposure draft will be up for tender and that the particular employment provider that wins that tender will then provide services within that region. That will mean, as I understand it—and perhaps the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) will explain this later—that only one person, one body or one corporation will provide employment services within that particular region.

If that is so, where then is the competition that is said will lead to a much better provision of services? I make that point again—if there is only one successful tenderer in each region, how can it be said that this is a system that will rely on competition? Isn't it rather a system that provides for 29 monopolies which people will have to go to if they want to find employment?
There are some very serious implications in that. On page 27 of the exposure draft, the following outline of the contract appears:

BREAK.PARA: Under the provisions of the legislation, contracts will be "Employment Services Agreements" (for employment services generally) and "Employment Assistance Agreements" (for Employment Assistance). This means that contracted service providers are bound by the provisions of the legislation—for example, Employment Assistance Providers may act as delegates of the Employment Secretary in negotiating an Employment Assistance Activity Agreement with a participant.

So, as I understand the scheme, a person who provides employment not only will have a monopoly but also, in certain respects, will have the powers of the employment secretary. A senior official of the Commonwealth will have the secretary's powers within that monopoly. That is a matter of considerable concern, I would have thought, for the way we are going to handle very vulnerable people under this legislation.

Under the present system we have CES officers, who are officials of the Commonwealth, and people can go down and deal with them. If they have any complaints, they can complain to their local member, to other people or to the Public Service itself and perhaps something can be done. But what is the position where you have private people taking over those functions and holding the powers that very senior officials within the government hold?

There is no doubt that the minister has turned her mind to that issue. There is set out in both the Reform of Employment Services Bill and the Reform of Employment Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill provisions that try to overcome the situation that might well be created by having private people do what was formerly done by the Public Service. In these are provisions which attempt, in any event, to make applicable to private agents the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act and the Ombudsman's act, and so on.

That raises this issue: if competition is going to be the order of the day and if it is going to provide the protections that are needed to ensure that various people—I will come to them—who are touched by this scheme are protected from injustice, why do we need these various provisions, this quite rigorous regime of cheques and balances, to keep the system in order? Is this a privatisation of a public scheme or a nation alisation of private providers of employment services? It could be looked at either way.

We have had a public system of providing employment, albeit under the last government private interests clearly were introduced to the scheme further down the ladder to enable services to be carried out. If we are going to go from a public system to a private system, what protections are we going to have? If the protections are those that are set out in the legislation, what do they do for the effectiveness with which the private providers provide the particular services they are supposed to provide?

You have a dichotomy here. You have a very difficult scheme. It is difficult because nothing is identified and it is not quite clear as to what should happen. As for the people who are going to go through the system—no matter whether they are the people who provide the services or accept the services—what is their position in trying to work out what the present scheme is all about?

As I understand the provisions of the legislation, the employment secretary is to make agreements with service providers on behalf of the Commonwealth. There are some tests which the minister will set out as to what these people who take on the contracts with the employment secretary should agree to.

I understand, at least, that there is going to be an official of the government who will make contracts with private providers of services to help people who are out of work. But when you look further into the legislation you find that, although the employment secretary can do these things, he has the power to delegate his functions to other people. He can delegate the very important function of trying to get proper providers of services for people who are out of work to any officer of his department or a member of the staff of the agency. We then come to the concept of an agency, which, as we have tried to trace our way through this morass, we have not heard of up until now.

If we look at the definitions section of the Reform of the Employment Services Bill 1996 we find that `agency' means the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency which was established by the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Act 1996. We say to ourselves that that must be a body which has specific purposes within the field of delivering services to the unemployed. But when we look at that act—the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Act 1997—it is not specific at all to the provision of services. As far as I can see, there is no expertise within the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency in terms of employment and getting jobs for people without them or for training people who need it so that they can get jobs. It is difficult to comprehend why there is this reference to the agency within this legislation.

If we go from the Reform of Employment Services Bill itself to the Reform of Employment Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1996, which is short and to a certain extent very sharp, in part 1 the whole of the Employment Services Act 1994 is repealed. This has already been spoken about. That means the end, of course, of the Commonwealth Employment Service. It might well have been a wise thing to keep that body in operation while this new scheme was tested, because, as the minister has said, this is the most radical change to employment services that has been brought forward for a long time. To do away in one sweep with the systems that we have had before when we are very unsure of the system that we are putting in place, and when the system that we are putting in place is in uncharted waters, seems to be courageous, to say the least.
There are a few things I would like to say in relation to the second reading speech which have already been said, but need to be said again. In the second reading speech the minister said:

The reforms to labour market services in the bills should also be seen in the broader context of the government's commitments to deficit reduction and budgetary discipline. These commitments are essential for increasing the growth capacity of the Australian economy and ultimately for delivering sustained reductions in unemployment.

If that did happen, then there could be nothing but praise for the scheme undertaken, but again it leads to confusion. What is the scheme about? Is it a scheme that is attempt ing to get people back into work, provide services to people and to help people regain their confidence and the skills that they need to work? Or is it to save the budget and to make sure that the deficit does not go any further so that more money can go into producing jobs? Or is it a bit of both and, if so, what balance is to be struck between them? The Commonwealth Employment Services is to be abolished by this radical change and surely these sorts of things should be planned and thought about before we go into this radical scheme.

On page two of the second reading speech six principles for the reform of the employment services are set out and when you look at them, people could not but praise the aspirations that they hold. People could have a great deal of trouble trying to work out just how these aspirations are going to be realised. I will just go through them very quickly. The first principle is:
The assistance to job seekers should be based on their individual needs and their capacity to benefit from it in terms of achieving an employment outcome.

What is there in this legislation, the exposure draft of the tendering conditions and in the contract itself that in any way gives any indication of how that is to be done, except to simply say that the private sector will fix it up somehow? That is the private sector that we trust to the extent of imposing all sorts of obligations upon them by making them applicable to the Crimes Act 1914, the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Privacy Act 1988, the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and so on. There seems to be great confusion there.
The second principle is:
Providers should have access to flexible forms of assistance that fit the needs of job seekers.
Of course, but how is that aspiration to be realised? The third principle is:
The incentive framework should reward providers of labour market assistance primarily for placing job seekers in real jobs, with additional incentives for those most in need.
Yes, but are we going to do that by giving 29 providers of labour market assistance the monopoly in each area that I discussed before? The fourth principle is:
A competitive market for employment placement services should separate purchaser from providers and ensure that providers operate on the basis of competitive neutrality.
I am not sure what that means. No doubt the minister, in her usual lucid way, will explain that. The fifth principle is:
Conditions for payment of income support for unemployed people should be linked closely with active employment assistant measures.
But as you read through the second reading speeches, the exposure drafts, the bills and the explanatory memorandum, none of that is explained. And, finally:
Job seekers and employers should be able to receive high quality and streamlined service from the agencies and providers with which they interact.

And of course they should be but, again, the problem is that these things are not explained to us. The real issue in this matter is how the proper aspirations, how the good ambitions that the minister has, can be realised, and that is not explained in the present circumstances. That is why this matter should be discussed, and discussed at length.

The other problem that I have is this. There is a scheme set up here but the proposals to improve the employment situation in Australia in the government's mind are such that it could easily take, it says, an alternative measure. It could get rid of all this legislation and use a means other than enactments to create what it wants. If it is so essential to have this legislation, why is there a strong alternative to be able to do without it? Just what are we going to provide for those people now out of work?

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all senators for their contribution to the debate, in spite of the fact that I disagree with a large portion of what has been said. I express some regret that it is clear that some senators still do not understand not only the government's intention, but also the legislative process that is in front of them—that is, what the bill actually says.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I could spend just a few minutes outlining what the government intends to do vis‐a‐vis this bill. What we intend to do is to pick up the best of Working Nation. We have been very critical of the previous government's Working Nation program where we think it failed, and we have disposed of those portions, as best we can, that we think did fail.

We think it was the wrong thing to put people on training programs when there was no job at the end. That might have satisfied the bureaucrats and kept them busy—whether they were in the public, private or community sector—but if, in the end, it did not result in a real job for the person who was on benefits and looking to get off benefits, we say you did not achieve the end that you wanted to achieve. There has never been any suggestion on our part that Working Nation was put together in bad faith. It might have had an eye on the electoral cycle, but it was not in bad faith.

I do not want to rehearse again and again the things that we think were wrong other than to say that to put people through programs that are not effective is not a sensible thing to do. As I have indicated, we have got rid of a significant number of those programs. With respect to those programs, to pay providers—that is, private providers not in the public sector, or community providers—for what we call an outcome—it was Labor that shifted originally to outcome payments—and to say that it is an outcome that you have put someone in a six‐month training program that does not necessarily result in a job, we think is the wrong thing.

For someone who is on a benefit and looking for a job, the outcome that they want is a job. They want a real lasting job that will be there when the Commonwealth money runs out. That is what they all want and I do not presume there is any disagreement about that. So we are shifting to a system where those people who get contracts from the Commonwealth will get paid when they get people jobs. It is just that simple.

I have spoken about the parts of Working Nation that I thought were a complete failure and a huge waste of money. Something like $780 million or $870 million in the previous financial year was spent on programs that had a 20 or 30 per cent effectiveness rate. If you were to go to the taxpayers of Australia and to the unemployed—people who are not yet paying tax—and say, `The government is concerned about the plight of unemployed Australians. Do you think it is a good thing if we spend towards a billion dollars on programs that only have a 20 or 30 per cent effectiveness rate or should we try for something better?', I would be very surprised if you found anyone who was not prepared to say, `You should try for something better.'

Unemployed Australians deserve better than what we were able to put together. I do not say that to imply that Labor just dished up a whole lot of crummy ineffective programs without caring. I think Labor genuinely tried in the Working Nation program to make a difference, but the point is that we could see fairly early on that it was not working. It was taking people off long‐term unemployment and just churning them around and they would come back onto short‐term unemployment.

In particular, another fault in the targeting of the program was that it was targeted only at the long‐term unemployed and not at those at risk of becoming long‐term unemployed. I have no difficulty with targeting the long‐term unemployed—they deserve our help above all others—but if you forget to look at the people at risk of falling into that bucket, then you are taking people out of the long‐term unemployed bucket as more people come in. And so we have made that alteration. I think that concludes what I want to say about the negatives of Working Nation.

The first positive aspect was that Labor clearly recognised that, when you are long‐term unemployed, it is damned hard to get a job. The services traditionally available from the CES may well not be appropriate. The people who were long‐term unemployed not just deserved, but needed, more targeted assistance—targeted to them. So they developed a system they called case management where some long‐term unemployed people—some, not all; there was never an uncapped, unlimited right of access to case management—got access to this case management.

BREAK.PARA: There was someone who would speak with you regularly, plan what you would be doing to get a job—whether you needed to have some training, whether you had grooming problems, whether you needed English language training, computer training, whatever—and they would try to generate opportunities for you. That was a very creative aspect of Working Nation. It recognised something that we all should have recognised years ago—that long‐term unemployed people need one‐on‐one assistance. That is one of the most creative aspects of Working Nation.

The second creative aspect was recognising that the public provider was not the be‐all and end‐all. Labor recognised that and said that with this proposal for working one on one together in case management they would not have a single provider, the CES; they would shift away from that. They created a portion of the CES called Employment Action Australia, and then said that this task of case managing people one on one would be divided up between the public provider, private providers and community providers—people like the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Lawrence and Centapact, who have a very real overriding interest, not just a money interest, in getting the contracts to help the long-term employed.

So they are the two creative aspects of Working Nation: looking at people on a one‐on‐one basis and spreading the work around so that there is a choice of provider, so that there is competition—it was Labor that introduced this—and that competition will work to produce better services for unemployed people. We think they were very creative aspects, and they are the aspects that we are picking up and wanting to expand. It is, as I say, just that simple.

There has been a couple of, I think, mis‐statements of the case. I understand Senator Evans was a little bit ungracious today in saying that the legislation before the house was abandoning the long-term employed, whereas in fact it is targeted primarily at the long-term unemployed and those at risk of going into the long‐term unemployment bucket and that is where about 90 per cent of the effort and money in relation to this matter goes. So we have taken that advice, recognised that aspect of Working Nation and added to it by saying that we will look at the people who are at risk of falling in as well and they are the people we want to give priority to in relation to government funds. We want them to be the first call.

I understand some of the other arguments that have been raised. Wouldn't it be nice if anybody could just walk in? If I felt like getting a different job, I could just walk into the CES and take up someone's time discussing options of where else I could be employed. I am sure some Labor people could offer a few suggestions, but wouldn't it be outrageous if someone with a job took up the time of the CES at the expense of someone who is long-term employed, does not have a job, is on a benefit and wants to get off it? I think, with respect, those on the other side have their priorities wrong.

We want to give our undivided attention to the long-term unemployed, the people who are on benefits and who want to get off those benefits. We have towards 800,000 people who are unemployed—and that statistic is from the ABS, not Social Security. Hundreds of thousands of people are on unemployment benefits—and they are not sitting around on a couch doing nothing. They are not, as I think it was Mr Beazley who said, sitting around on a couch or out causing trouble on the streets. The vast majority of these people want a job.

Our legislation is very tightly targeted. I admit that. We are not now saying any man and his dog can come in and get this help. Any man and his dog can come in and get first up access to a world-class vacancy database. They can look for jobs in their local area, in their state or Australia wide. They can search to their heart's content without having to be in a subservient position before a clerk at the counter. They can look through one industry and, if they think they would like to try another industry, they can look through that.

If anyone has not used the touch screens at the CES, I strongly recommend that they do. They are a world-class innovation in delivering services to the unemployed. And that, of course, is available to everyone. But when people want to say, `I want more than that. I want some real help and impetus in getting a job,' we think it is the appropriate decision—and I make no bones about this and we make no apologies for it—that every dollar we can spend should be spent on those who are on a benefit, who are unemployed and looking for work. They should come before anybody else.

I think that concludes my general summary of where we want to go, and I will now quickly go through a couple of other points that have been made. I note that Senator Kernot thinks there is scope for fly‐by‐night shonks to get in. I do not see how she can come to that conclusion. By and large, it has not happened with the case management arrangements that Labor introduced. If anything, there was more scope under those arrangements, but that did not happen. We are confident, on the basis of the experiment tried by Labor, that the extension of this experiment will be as good, if not better, in terms of the monitoring of contracts. In fact, I am sure it will be better.

Senator Kernot says there is no assurance of outcomes. What assurance of outcomes do unemployed people have today? What assurance does anybody who wants to vote against this legislation offer that the existing system offers them? We have had pretty well 13 years of the existing system—the last two with some very welcomed modifications—and what can we say that system produces? Can anyone over there say that they can guarantee an outcome to someone? It seems to me a little cheap and flippant to come in and say to us, `Well, you can't guarantee—' when none of you could either when you were in government. You know no government can give people an absolute guarantee that, if they go through this process, they will get a job. But we can give this guarantee: our first priority will be the people on benefits who want to get a job, and they will come before everybody else.

I sense a little deja vu in this debate that perhaps we are wasting our time and going through an act we have all seen before in that Senator Kernot has made up her mind: she is philosophically opposed to the concept of competition providing better services. I think she and a couple of other senators mentioned they are opposed to privatisation.

We can have a debate on privatisation if we want, and we would say they are the party that always say they are against privatisation—with hands up and promise, promise, promise never to privatise the Commonwealth Bank—whoops, we will sell half; promise, promise, promise we will not sell the other—whoops, now we think we will; promise, promise, promise we will not sell Qantas—whoops, we will; promise, promise, promise we are opposed to privatisation—whoops, we have to do it in New South Wales; promise, promise, promise we are against a sales tax—whoops, we have to have a bed tax in New South Wales.

Really, it does come to the point where the people opposite make people over here wonder how on earth they ever stayed in power for 13 years. I have to say that we on this side have to take responsibility for that, because they were so hopeless as a government that they could not have got elected on their record. It must have been because we were not good enough. It certainly was not that they were good enough in the job.

So we can have a debate on privatisation, but in the end I would say, `Hold on, let me just point out, before we waste a lot of time, that this bill is not about privatisation.' It is not about privatisation. I hear this rubbish that people are peddling about privatising the CES or abolishing the CES. What an unmitigated load of rubbish. You people sitting over there, those of you who can read—and, looking around, I think everybody there can; most of the senators here I think have had a pretty reasonable interest in this, except for Senator Brown, who I have never seen show any interest in this bill at all—understand that it is not about privatisation.

We are simply doing two things with the CES. We are sensibly saying—and you have agreed to this, thank heavens—`Why are we making unemployed people run between the CES and the Department of Social Security?' What idiot ever devised a formula that said, `Put the two close together so unemployed people can walk between them'? Once you have grasped the concept that unemployed people have to go to both, why not, in their interest, put both together in the shopfront? We thank the Senate for agreeing to that very sensible reform. But of course that is only the shopfront aspect of the CES.

The remaining parts of the CES that do the work of job placement, labour exchange and now the case management will be put together in one separate unit, which will be the public employment placement enterprise taken out of the Public Service and corporatised. I have spent hours and hours successfully arguing for the benefits of those people. I think the union were very surprised. They came with their war sticks ready to do battle and slightly had their breath taken away by the offer we could make. I know the CPSU do not want the remaining part of the CES to be corporatised, but they cannot say that they think we could offer better conditions than have been offered.

People can return to the Public Service and have lifetime access, if they stay there, to Commonwealth super—that is for the individual staffers. For those of you who are interested, perhaps we can go through some of those details in the committee stage—almost unprecedented in the care that I have personally taken and senior officers in the department have taken to ensure very good staffing conditions for those people. But still we have people saying, `No, we're not going to let you go ahead with this because we are more concerned about the conditions of people with a job, and we are more concerned with the ideology of shifting something into a company than we are with letting you proceed with something which might have a chance of delivering better outcomes.' So it has been, I think, a slightly depressing debate.

I just want to make one more point with respect to Senator Margetts's contribution. Senator Margetts raised the issue of the capacity to benefit test. For those who are not familiar with this, it is a test that basically says, when a job seeker comes to this shopfront, `Would you be suitable? Would you benefit from what we call intensive employment assistance'—because it will be slightly different from what you refer to as case management; but we know what we mean: one‐on‐one assistance—`or is there no point in putting you through that?' Everybody agrees. I have spoken to dozens of people in community organisations and there is an agreement that there are some people who would not benefit from that.

But Senator Margetts goes on and says, `So what happens then?' I think she said that what we are doing is putting them aside and making them `basket cases'—I understand that they are the words she used this morning. I do not know whether she has not been keeping up with the program. But, as a consequence of the very wide negotiations this government has had since announcing this in May last year so that everyone would have a clear idea of what was what—we issued a broad outline of what we wanted to do and consulted widely on that—we worked with the community organisations. They agree that, for someone who has a drug problem, an alcohol problem, a mental health problem or some other problem that is stopping them from getting work, it is not fair to put them through some six months or 12 months of assistance when you know that, if that problem is not fixed, they are not going to get a job.

So we have developed the community support program. We are brokering people who will primarily be community providers to, in a sense, case manage these people. If you have a drug, alcohol or mental health problem, there is a fair chance that you do not know where to go to get the appropriate help; you do not know how much assistance is out there. So we have put up an $11 million program to pay community providers to help these people get the appropriate help and put them in a condition—that is, get rid of the drug, alcohol, mental health or whatever problem—so they can come back, have a capacity to benefit and have a real chance of getting a job. So, Senator Margetts, we might disagree on lots of things, but if you are going to drop a bucket on somebody's program, I ask you to at least have the decency to read the program properly before you do drop the bucket.

The other point I want to make is that the reason we need to debate this bill very thoroughly is not purely for what is in the bill but for what the minister intends to do by administrative action on a range of measures that have been considered part of normal employment services in Australia. In fairness to the minister those announcements were made in her statement following the last budget and so they are out in the public arena. But it is important that the parliament debate those issues. That is why the opposition has sought to address some of those issues via amendment to these bills—because these are important public policy issues that otherwise would not be considered by the parliament. For all those reasons we think it is very important that these bills be debated. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans made brief remarks about alleged threats to withdraw if I did not get my way—selfish little me. Perhaps, `little' is not the appropriate adjective, but you know what I mean. That is not the case. What we have tried to do is make it abundantly clear that there are some amendments that will not be acceptable, and since time immemorial, it has been the case that governments will accept some amendments, and not others.

SPEECH.PARA: In the spirit of putting our cards on the table, I have simply wanted to say that these things are unacceptable; other things we can talk about. I have had, I think, some reasonably useful discussions with Senator Kernot. I do not think that we are going to get there, but there are a number of things that I have pointed out where she has seen merit in what we have said and a number of things that she has raised that we have said we can look at. Senator Brown made the point about profit being such a dirty word. But the dawning of that, hopefully, will eventually come; Senator Brown is not a spring chicken, but it will eventually come to him, I am sure.

Perhaps I could explain why I think that is an excellent motive. Why will the profit motive help the long‐term unemployed better than anything we have ever tried before? It is quite simply this: if you go into the CES now, as well‐ intentioned as everybody there is—and I think they work very hard to do a pretty good job—you can strike someone on a bad hair day, as they say, or even someone who is right up and ready to go, but it does not mean a thing to that person's job. The person in the CES still has their job whether they get you one or not. So it does not matter. We can be poor performers, medium performers, excellent performers. Every week or fortnight we can put out our hand and take the money.

Similarly, for private and community providers that were contracted under the Working Nation program, they would do their best; I am sure they would do their best. But they get money for putting you on a training program. So when an unemployed person goes into one of these agencies, they may well feel like, and be seen as, someone who is down on their luck and it being a case of, `Aren't we all big Joes, we're going to try and do our best for them. Isn't that nice?' It is for you if you are the warm person with the nice feeling in your heart, `I'm going to try and do my best for you, but by the way I'll keep my job whatever happens,' but it is not so good for the unemployed person, to feel as if they are on the receiving end of some charitable exercise of goodwill by the government and others. I do not think that is the appropriate position to put unemployed people in.

Look at the new system that we are proposing. That is one where all of these people get paid their money on whether they get you a job. So all of a sudden the unemployed person who comes in is not someone who is down on their luck, and it being a case of, `Oh, I'll try and help them if I can and I'll keep my job anyway, whether I get them a job or not.' All of a sudden the unemployed person is a very important person to every employment provider because the only way an employment provider will survive and get money from the Commonwealth is if they keep putting unemployed people into jobs.

So now the unemployed person, under the system I want to create, will be the most important person in every employment placement enterprise. Those people in those employment placement enterprises, whether it is the public provider, the private providers or the community providers, will not keep their jobs as employment providers if they do not provide employment. The profit motive is an excellent motive to get people to focus on what is important in their job, and that is getting other people jobs.

Senator Cooney asked me briefly about the tender document that he has seen. I do not think we have yet got a copy of that, or we might have, but I have not had a chance to look. Senator Cooney referred to the five employment services identified and, as I gather, his point was that he was not too sure how it spelt out that the majority of people who would be helped would be the long‐term unemployed.

I just wanted to indicate to him that the first four services that he mentioned will take about 10 per cent of the Commonwealth's money. I think I indicated—if I did not, I will now—that we are not walking away from all other employment services. There is the new enterprise incentives scheme, for example, which would come under self‐employment assessments; it is one of the effective Working Nation programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of ours!

—Senator Mackay, you can proudly say, `One of ours.' If it was, well and good. If you were here earlier, and you may have been, I have been at pains to point out the creative and excellent parts of Working Nation. The NEIS scheme is a fabulous scheme; it has a very high success rate either in getting people to generate their own employment or, if their own business does not work, at least getting them into other employment.
—Pity you cut funding.

—Senator, I am trying to stop interjections because we do want to have a peaceful and orderly debate, but you do say, `Pity we cut funding.' Pity there was an $8 billion deficit. And haven't we seen the benefit of a government that is prepared to make difficult decisions, a government that is prepared to go out and wear the odium of saying to people, `You're going to get less or have to pay more,' because what we have seen is four interest rate cuts in a row. For anybody who has got a loan, a housing loan or a small business, that puts more money in their pocket than any government could ever do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans says, `Oh well, it doesn't help the unemployed.' SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney, the remaining 90 per cent goes into the last program, intensive employment assistance, which, as I say, builds on case management—not exactly the same, but builds on it—and is different only in the respect that under the case management—which I freely identify is a creative part of Working Nation—you may need one‐on‐one help. For instance, Senator Cooney, if you are unemployed and I am your case manager, it is very wise to recognise that you need one‐ on‐one help, but then my hands were tied behind my back because I had to choose from a range of Commonwealth programs in which to help you.

We are changing that. Senator Cooney, we will say you are most likely to get a job, so there would not be much money attached to helping you, but there will be an amount of money attached to helping you—a bigger amount if you were more difficult to get employed and even bigger if you were very difficult get employed. That money would notionally come to me, if I were an employment provider. It would not actually come to me. I could use it as I saw fit to get you a job.

So instead of having to choose out of just some limited programs, with my hands tied behind my back, I could actually choose what you really needed, and if you needed a bit of one program and a bit of another, I could put together what you wanted. That is the way in which we are changing the case management system. Having recognised the one‐on‐one system as important, we are giving the case manager the flexibility to give the unemployed person what they need. But that is where 90 per cent of the money goes—to the long‐term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —(1.40 p.m.)—Thank you for that question. You were probably otherwise engaged this morning. No doubt had you had your television monitor on and you may have been able to hear part of the debate this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: My position has not changed from that which I briefly discussed with you outside the chamber yesterday—that is, there are amendments which the government thinks it can accept. It is not unusual for a government to say prior to the debate of some bills and amendments which are known, that some of the proposed amendments will not be acceptable. This is something that has happened time and time again.

Governments, if they are doing the right thing by a chamber, will indicate what they would be prepared to accept and what they would not be prepared to accept. In some cases, if a government will not accept certain amendments then they simply might not proceed and things will stay as they are. In other circumstances, the government would be able to go another way. You choose, senator, to describe that as an extraparliamentary route and it was with some distress I heard you say that you think I have an attitude that parliament does not matter. It is precisely because I do not have that attitude that this bill is before this place. There is a legislative—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. We are very grateful.

—Do not thank me. Once you have spent 12 years in opposition, as I did, you will have a very good understanding of the parliamentary process and a respect for it. Your side may even grow to like the clerks once you realise how useful having institutional memory and independence is.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great respect for the parliamentary process. When there is a choice between outlining your new plans and giving them a legislative framework or going under existing legislation—not by‐passing parliament and trying to do something in some shonky way—that has been used for years and years by governments of both persuasions—at least by the previous government—I say let us go the legislative route, precisely out of a respect for parliament.

It is not unusual for a government to identify that there might be a number of things that would be unacceptable and then not proceed with the legislation. In some cases that means you come back to nothing happening. In other cases, if it is possible under other legislation to proceed then the government might have to proceed albeit by way of a slightly different path.

I do not think this is unusual. Out of respect for the process, I have tried to indicate to senators what the government's position is. Not out of disrespect but out of respect for the process I have tried to indicate that there is another available path which senators, in casting their votes, would well understand. I think it would be catching senators out and, if you like, ambushing them and not informing them properly if I were not perfectly open and honest with the chamber about what the government's intentions are.

BREAK.PARA: I will give you one example of something I think is completely unacceptable. My reading of amendment 11—it might now be amendment 9—which relates to clause 9(a), is that it gives a monopoly on labour exchange services to the public employment placement enterprise. The government thinks that is completely inappropriate. We accepted the creative part of Working Nation which set up competition between the public provider, the private provider and community providers for what Labor described as case management. We think that competition has worked well and can be extended to the labour exchange.

We think it is completely inappropriate to exclude community providers like Centapak, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Salvation Army and private providers from labour exchange work. We simply have an attitude where we will give the money for labour exchange work to those who do the labour exchange effectively and it will be distributed around accordingly.

We think it would be quite inappropriate for that proposal to be overridden by an amendment, and we would not accept it. I say that in the spirit of trying to be respectful to parliament, rather than in a threatening way. It might be uncomfortable, in a political sense, for opponents of this change to realise that the government may be able to go another way. It would not be exactly the same. I understand that.
