BREAK.XREF: REFORM OF EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996 [1997]

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Reform of Employment Services Bill 1996 [1997] and government amendment No 1. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

—I was just asking the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) about the long‐term unemployed, who are not going to benefit from this program. I thank you, Minister, for saying I am good at the figures. Although that will not help any of these people, it means that there must be some accuracy to these figures. Seventy‐eight thousand people will have some assistance through the proposed program and 151,600 will not. Can you tell the committee how that 78,000 will be selected from the nearly quarter of a million people who would be wanting to get some assistance to get back to work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be pretty well the same as under the existing arrangements for dealing with long‐term unemployed people to go on to case management, and that is that as soon as places become available people go into them.

—That is correct then? The impression we were getting a little while ago was that those who had had the longest travail in unemployment were not necessarily going to be those who got to the front of the queue at all. There is going to be a selection process on parameters that you say exist at the moment, but it is not going to be a case of the people who have been out of work the longest getting to the front of the queue. I am just asking you to give a brief summary that indicates how you are going to determine which people should be at the front of that queue and who will be the people of top priority, as you describe them, when they go into one of these agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens at the moment is that, to the best of everyone's ability, there is a fair mix of those who are long‐term unemployed. We will continue the practice of the previous government where, for example, in relation to placement on new work opportunity programs, sometimes there has been an indication in some areas that all the successful applicants would have to be, for example, unemployed for two or more years, or unemployed for up to five years. But at the same time people who had become long‐term unemployed—being unemployed for 12 months—were not excluded. So, in a sense, it is a mix and match to try to get a fair distribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that there is a concern in the community that, with this choice going to private agencies, the parameters might change. The Commonwealth Employment Service has got a long experience with this. But, when you put it into the hands of a for‐profit organisation whose profit comes from placing people from their books—their return is directly related to their ability to skill people and get them into jobs—how are they going to determine which people they are going to give that advantage to? Is that not going to be shaped by what they see as their priority in making people the better equipped to get into a job, rather than the people's priority to get a job?

SPEECH.PARA: Can you see what I am getting at? The problem I have is that, whereas a government agency can really be all the way down the line concerned for the individual, we now have an overriding concern coming in which is for the non‐government agency to make money. That is fair enough—it is a legitimate concern, and it is well recognised; that is what private enterprise is about. But it is not the same as the job seeker's priority. It is not the same as the long‐term unemployed person's priority that she and he get the best advantage if they are the least advantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated, the process of sharing around the support available will be as fair as it is under the existing arrangements introduced by the previous government. It may well be that we can make it fairer. We certainly think this system will be better. You ask me: `What about when someone goes to a private agency?' You are putting, as I understand you, the notion that the private agency will look after first the people who are easier to place, because that is how they will get their outcome fee—from putting someone in a job—and they will therefore choose to ignore the long‐term unemployed. I think that briefly is your proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is not going to work like that. It simply is not going to work like that because the service delivery agency will be the one which refers unemployed people to an EPE or a PEPE, and the EPE or PEPE cannot refuse. You cannot have pick and choose. Someone with a blindfold and a mask over their head could see that, if you let private and community and even public providers choose whom they will look after, they will choose the easiest first. So I quite agree with you, if that is your sentiment. There will not be that choice. They cannot choose who comes in the door and they cannot have only the easy to place people; they will get a fair mix. So, at the end of the tender period, someone who followed the passage that you think they will—that is, ignored the harder cases—would not have a good outcome. If they do not have good outcomes—if their success rate is not high—they lower their chances of getting another tender. So in order to keep in the game they have got to keep performing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow on from what Senator Brown said. Minister, could you give us an idea of the sorts of people to whom the employment secretary will delegate these powers? That may help to get over Senator Brown's problems. While we are talking about the delegation of power, to what sorts of people—I do not mean the class—will the employment secretary be delegating his powers under section 9?
—Officers in the agency, I am advised, at probably ASO3 or 4 level.
—That is under section 119. Can we be assured that they will be at that level in both cases? I am very interested that you would delegate powers under section 9 to officers of that level.
—Yes. I am advised that that is the expectation and it is exactly the same as under the current employment services act. In other words, it would be no different from that, as I am advised.
—Just to clarify that—can the entities that will be delivering these services be engaged by officers at the ASO3‐ASO4 level?
—There might be some confusion. As I understood your question, you were referring to—
—I was referring to two sections.
—You were referring to section 20, and that is the one I have answered.

—Yes, and at the same time I asked about section 9. I thought you said it would be the same in respect of both. It would surprise me if that were the situation. To what level of officer would he delegate his powers under section 9?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it may well be that the secretary does not delegate under section 9 but takes that responsibility entirely himself. That decision has not been entirely made. But, as I think you gather from our reluctance to immediately make that decision, it would be at a very senior level.

—With the allocation of a group of unemployed people to one of the private agencies, it is to be expected that at the end of a period of time some of those people will still not have jobs or will have gotten jobs but not been able to retain them. What happens to those people? What is the government's view as to where they go from there? Does the private service agency have to retain them until they are placed in a continuing job, or do they go back to the public Commonwealth employment service agency? How does the government assess performance—not just quantitatively by the number of people it places in jobs but qualitatively by the number of people who have been long‐term unem ployed and have great difficulty getting jobs—in determining whether that service agency gets future contractual opportunities out of this arrangement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two things to say. There is a tendering process at the moment through ESRA which has demonstrated that it is possible to assess whether people are successful at placing people at levels 1, 2 and 3. It has been demonstrated that that assessment is possible and will continue to be possible.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of consultations, we have made an additional change. If someone is in case management for 12 months at the moment, that is pretty well the end of it. They go back on the queue. That can be a very bad thing for both the unemployed person and the provider. If you have been looking after someone for 12 months, and you are really close, and an opportunity comes up three weeks later, outside the 12‐month period, you both lose. There is no incentive for the employment placement provider to ring you up and get you the job, unless they really like you, because they are not going to get any money. That is a very bad thing for the unemployed person. For that reason, we have indicated that there is a possibility of extending the time period during which we will count whether you have got someone a job. If you have had them for 12 months, and they get a job a month later, it is obviously to the benefit of unemployed people and providers if that is taken into account. The short answer is, it will be the existing system with some improvements.

TALK.START.PARA: —If a five per cent failure rate is acceptable—that is not going to worry you, when getting another contract—what is to stop an agency assessing which are the five per cent who are least able to get a job and sitting on them by giving them second‐rate service and not promoting them forward? I am looking at the people who have extreme difficulty getting a job. You are assuring me that this is going to enhance their opportunities. I am trying to find out what it is in this system that is going to enhance their opportunities, because I have not yet heard one word about how this system is going to improve the lot of long‐term unemployed people of all ages—of whom there are a quarter of a million in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not sure whether you were saying that the Service Delivery Agency or someone to whom they referred an unemployed person would be so negligent with respect to a long‐term unemployed person. I hope you are not suggesting that of the service delivery agency, because that is the equivalent of suggesting that the CES, which is a government agency, would do that.
—I am talking about the private agencies, which are, as yet, untested.

—If you are talking about the providers to whom someone has been referred, can I say two things. I have already answered that question for you on a number of occasions. You have worded it differently, but the answer comes the same because it is the same question: how will we monitor?

SPEECH.PARA: I have indicated that it has clearly been displayed by the previous government's efforts in setting up ESRA that it is possible to monitor the performance of private and community providers—and, for that matter, EAA—on the basis of their capacity to deal with people according to their levels of difficulty. It is possible to judge their performance, and we already do that. The previous government did it, and we have continued with that. That is possible. That is the answer to your question. There will be close monitoring, as there is now, of the performance of private and community providers. To that extent, there is not much change.

Senator, I wish that you had taken up the offers of a briefing which were made on a number of occasions by my office to the two Green senators—I understand that you do not like to be referred to as the Greens as a party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, we do the best we can, Senator. We have had very extensive consultations with the community groups who are concerned about this situation and with the unemployed themselves. That is a matter of priority. We have got extremely valuable information out of them. But here I am in this situation where, as you said, I have asked the question three or four times from different directions, and you have come up with the same answer. That leaves me with the same concerns on behalf of the people we have been consulting with in the community and for whom we feel a very keen responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I am here debating this with you today, because I am very concerned that this is the wrong way to go in their interests. We have a diametrically different viewpoint and it is only the Greens, of all the components of this Senate, that voted against the second reading of this legislation. So be it. But we will maintain those close relationships. It may mean that at times we do not have the time for extensive consultations with your office. We will do the best we can.

That said, I retain a very deep concern that the increasing privatisation, on a for‐profit basis, of the placement of people into the limited number of jobs available in this country, where it is clear we are 800,000 to a million jobs short of the number required for full employment, is going to be a matter of great concern. I think it is headed, as far as many unemployed people in this country are concerned, in the wrong direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the debate has ranged a bit broader than the exact terms of the proposed amendment. I hope my remarks have been relevant to that.
—You are right on the first; I will not make a judgment on the second, Senator Harradine.

—I invite you to make a judgment on what I am about to say. I ask the minister a question: this measure is of great importance, I imagine, to the government, and I assume that the government feels that the outcomes of this measure will be of great benefit to the unemployed. That being the case, is it the wish of the government and the minister to ensure that this legislation is debated by the parliament and that each and every member of the parliament who has a great interest in this measure should have the opportunity to consider it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated to you that there are two clear paths open. There is nothing shonky about either path—
—What about my question?

—I am coming to that. The government's preference is for the new legislation. It is more difficult in a legislative sense but easier in an administrative sense. With the other path, the legislation is already there but it is more difficult in an administrative sense. I have indicated to you that there are some key aspects of the legislation which the government believes are essential to our reforms, and I have indicated that, if the government is of a view that we cannot proceed in that sense, we will have to go the other route. There is, additionally, a time problem in terms of getting the process—3,000 people inquiring about tenders and an enormous amount of work to be done. This first tender is worth nearly $2 billion, so there is a very big task ahead. There is a time problem every week you delay. That certainly would be a pressure to choose the alternative path.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to tell you my hopes are dwindling for the first option, which is my preferred option, because I am informed that we have spent an hour and 20 minutes debating one clause. I certainly do not include you in this, because you have asked two questions, you are getting to exactly the same thing each time and I know what you are on about. But this chamber has spent an hour and 20 minutes debating the clause—I hope the nation is holding its breath—that the start date be changed from 1 December 1997 to 9 March 1998. If it takes an hour and 20 minutes to do that, the government may come to the conclusion that we are never going to get this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That is totally unfair, if that is the way the minister is going to deal with these particular questions. I am not responsible for whatever other questions have been asked but, let us face it, I think they were questions relevant overall to the legislation, and maybe we will not have to recanvass those matters when we come to the specific clauses. Let us hope not. So far as I am concerned, I am not wanting to delay this measure at all. In fact, this government amendment is extending the date of operation of the legislation from 1 December this year to 9 March next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked you a specific question: given the fact that every single member of parliament will be interested in the basis of this legislation and hopeful for its outcome, is the government prepared to give the opportunity to every member of the parliament, both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives, to debate the matter and to give the benefit to the government of their consideration of the matter?

I would like to believe—I know some people do—that all wisdom resides in the Senate. Certainly some people consider that all wisdom resides in the government. But there is the House of Representatives. This measure has been introduced into this chamber. I hope I am wrong, but what the minister seems to be indicating is that, if this chamber moves amendments, the government would then consider scrapping the bill altogether, without giving the House of Representatives and all those brilliant people in the House of Representatives an opportunity to give full consideration to this matter. I do not think that is a fair crack of the whip.

Indeed, there will be, no doubt, from the government in the House of Representatives considered views that will be down in Hansard which a person like me will be able to take into account if and when the matter comes before this chamber again. I am not a member of a party and I am not bound by party discipline. I hope to judge matters on their merits and I like to hear the debate. I happen to read what people say too in the House of Representatives from time to time about measures that this chamber is considering.

In all of the circumstances, I do not want to delay this measure. I hope we can get it over and done with this afternoon here so that the matter can go down to the House of Representatives, as this measure was introduced in this house. If you are saying that the government, depending on what we do this afternoon, is prepared to ditch the whole thing then you are certainly not giving the government or the people of Australia the benefit of the considerations of the measure that might take place in the House of Representatives. All I am asking, minister, is this: can you advise the chamber that, no matter what happens here, the matter will go down to the House of Representatives for its consideration?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, you are right that not all wisdom resides in the Senate, although I would indicate to you that I think the majority does. I often have the view that the lower House is not called the lower House without good reason. It is, nonetheless, the House where government is formed.

SPEECH.PARA: By good sense of the Australian people, both the coalition parties have a very substantial majority down in that chamber and I can assure you they are all very much in favour of this bill. I can assure you that, in the event of a debate down there, the coalition members will be very strongly opposed to the amendments. This has been discussed. As you know, Senator, even though you are not a member of a party, as you rightly identify, the parties in their party rooms do discuss things and there is a very clear intention on the government's behalf to proceed.

Senator, I just ask you to consider this. When the government was considering these reforms, had we chosen a different path to operate under existing legislation, as is available, you would have no complaint because the government would be entitled to say, `We are the government and we are acting under existing legislation.' Irksome as it may be, the government can act under existing legislation. If we had just gone ahead, we might have had a debate and you might have said I should not have made certain decisions, but you would not say I was acting out of power or improperly because I would be acting under existing legislation. That choice is there for the government.

I have indicated to you there are two aspects to this. Firstly, the government's intention is being frustrated. As I have told you, I intend to place the long-term unemployed who are on benefits at the top of every employment queue I possibly can and I am determined to do it. Secondly, I have indicated to you there is a timing problem. The government has not been irresponsible in this respect.

These changes were announced in May last year. You say you want a considered debate. There has been very broad consultation on this matter, including with a large portion of the welfare organisations, who indicate to me they are in favour of these changes. I do not know who the Greens have been talking to. Certainly you know some of the people that I know who are very much in favour of these changes proceeding. I have tried to indicate to you there is a timing problem. Put it this way: the government would have to consider its position.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (lines 3 to 11), omit the clause, substitute:
The objects of this Act are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to establish mechanisms to deliver employment services, including employment assistance, in a manner which will ensure that:

TAB.TAB: (i) all Australians have access to high quality labour exchange services, regardless of where they live; and
(ii) employment services provided to persons are based on the individual circumstances of persons using the services; and
(iii) employment services are provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner; and
(iv) employment services are provided in accordance with high ethical and professional standards and with respect to the right of users of the services to privacy; and
(v) Australia's obligations under International Labour Organisation conventions are met; and

PARA.TAB: (b) insofar as is consistent with the objectives set out in paragraph (a), to permit the establishment of a competitive market for the provision of employment services, including employment assistance; and
(c) insofar as is consistent with the objectives set out in paragraph (a), to provide for flexibility in the forms of employment services, including employment assistance, that are available.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought the debate on this employment services bill might take some time. Having seen the debate that the government's largely perfunctory amendment took, it may well take a very great time. I too do not wish to delay the proper debate on this at all but, from the opposition's point of view, it seems that this amendment seeks to express in the objects clause an alternative model to the one proposed by the government. In that sense, I think it is an important amendment and one which is a key to the sort of ideological debate that is occurring over this bill.

This amendment of ours seeks to replace a fairly small objects clause in the government's bill which talks mainly about mechanisms to deliver employment services and establishing a competitive market. The amendment which we have moved seeks to establish mechanisms to deliver employment services, but in a manner which will ensure that: all Australians have access to high quality labour exchange services; employment services provided to persons are based on the individual circumstances; employment services are provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner; employment services are provided in accordance with high ethical and professional standards; and, Australia's obligations under the ILO conventions are met. Of course, that is in so far as is consistent with those objectives to permit the establishment of a competitive market for the provision of employment services and, further, in so far as is consistent with those objectives to provide for flexibility in the forms of employment services.

As I said, this seeks to provide the framework for our amendments to the bill in toto which seeks to replace the government's model, if you like, by retaining the commitment that we have had as a nation since 1946 to universal access to labour exchange services. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has, in her explanations to the chamber so far in the committee stage, sought to set up a straw man. She said that it is a choice of whom you help, that her commitment is to help the long‐term unemployed, that every public dollar will go to them. Of course, that is code for saying the public dollar will no longer go to 400,000 Australians who are currently eligible for assistance from the CES. It is code for taking services off other people.

If you read the second reading speech of the minister, you might struggle to find this measure because it was glossed over. The emphasis was all on the assistance to the long-term unemployed and their new competitive regime. The Labor opposition is saying that that is fine. Unlike the Greens, we did not oppose the second reading of this bill because we are not seeking to prevent the government setting up that competitive regime. Nothing in any of our amendments is intended to, or will, prevent the government establishing the competitive regime for the intensive employment assistance programs.

But we will not be party to the removal of access to basic labour exchange services for all Australians, and that is what this bill seeks to do. By virtue of a decision announced by the minister not contained in the bill, and not given any emphasis in the second reading speech, those persons who are not `eligible persons', which is the new phrase, will not be entitled to any measures of assistance from the old CES or the new PEPE.

`Eligible persons' effectively means persons on unemployment benefits. Those who are not eligible for unemployment benefits are entitled to nothing from the CES or PEPE. What the minister has said is that those persons will be left to fend for themselves. That is, those newly arrived migrants whom we now deny unemployment benefits to until they have finished their waiting period will not be able to access publicly funded labour exchange services in this country. Women seeking to re‐enter the work force or women who have a working spouse will be ineligible to access those services.

A whole range of people—those who are made redundant or are retrenched, who for income or asset test purposes are excluded from unemployment benefit or who are too old or too young or what have you—will no longer be able to go to their local CES or PEPE and get the advantage of labour exchange services. So this measure is largely about trying to ensure that we have a continuation of basic, universal access to labour exchange services.
This is not a radical measure. The minister, on this occasion, is the radical in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As ever.

—As ever. We are adopting largely the conservative position. This is the conservative ideology that I do not know that the minister is all that wedded to but it certainly seems to have the numbers in cabinet these days. This is the decision to exclude people, to basically say to people, `If you are not receiving unemployment benefit, you are going to fall into the fee‐for‐service regime.' Make no mistake: the cumulative effect of these amendments is to establish a fee‐for‐service regime for unemployed persons in this country who are not in receipt of benefits. That is the logical conclusion to the constructionist market.

SPEECH.PARA: We are seeking in these amendments to ensure that the existing services and rights of Australians to have access to high quality labour exchange services are continued and protected. We are not seeking to give people rights or services they do not have currently; we are seeking to protect those basic rights—rights that are contained in our obligations under the ILO convention, rights that have been accepted on a bipartisan basis in this country since 1946, rights that have never been publicly argued against, except in the 1993 Fightback document.

This government did not go to the last election arguing that these people should lose their rights to labour exchange services. This is a measure taken to punish those who are unemployed but not able to access unemployment benefits. What we seek to do in these amendments is protect those rights but also set up what we think are reasonable objectives for a piece of legislation like this. The rights are: to be treated in a fair, just and expeditious manner, to have high ethical and professional standards applied and to have assurance that the employment services provided to persons are based on their individual circumstances.

This is in keeping with the government's approach in terms of the competitive market, but we want to make sure that the objectives spell out very clearly that these are objectives of the legislation and that all the other measures in the bill have to be measured against those proper objectives for the legislation.

As I say, we do not seek to prevent the competition model being implemented in terms of the more intensive employment assistance measures; what we say though is that every Australian has a right to those basic labour exchange services. In doing so, we give voice to our ILO commitments.

I know that the minister is keen to indicate that people will have access to the service delivery agency—and they will—but I took the opportunity to revisit a CES the other day to absolutely confirm in my own mind what those services will be. They are defined in the minister's speech on the second reading and in the tender documents.

I think it is important that people actually have a look at those, because the minister's defence has been that people will still be able to go to the Commonwealth service delivery agency and access services and that this somehow meets our ILO obligations. Well, anyone who reads the ILO convention and reads the government's definition of the self‐help assistance will see quite clearly that it does not meet our ILO convention obligations at all.

BREAK.PARA: The definition in the minister's speech on the second reading—and I think it is consistent with the tender documents—is that:

Self help assistance will be available at the agency to all job seekers. It would include access to: job vacancy displays, other employment and training information and facilities such as computers and telephones.
That is, they can look at the displays, they can read pamphlets about education and training, and they can make a telephone call.

But what they do not get is basic labour exchange services, the basic labour exchange services that are guaranteed by the ILO convention and that have been provided by the CES for the last 50 years. The government is trying to have us believe that their self‐help facilities, which are so basic and will be available at the agency, somehow meet their obligations to 400,000 or so unemployed people in Australia.

Quite clearly, the ILO convention—and I will not take the time of the Senate by reading a great deal of it—describes in article 6 the sort of service that is required to be met as part of our commitment. That talks about things like the job matching the basic labour exchange services, as are defined in the government's own documentation as being labour exchange services.

Quite clearly, the government has not met its obligations under its proposal to provide labour exchange services to all persons. It seeks to ration further the dollars available to unemployed in Australia by removing 400,000 or so unemployed persons from eligibility to anything but looking at displays, taking pamphlets and making a telephone call. That is not the sort of commitment that this country should be making to those large numbers of unemployed persons. And our objects clause, as proposed, will set out very clearly that we as a parliament think that Australians ought to continue to enjoy access to basic assistance in seeking employment.

This is not some unreasonable request, as I have said before; this is seeking the maintenance of a service that we have decided as a community for the last 50 years ought to be available. To pretend to set up a straw man argument to say that the minister is really only interested in providing assistance for the long‐term unemployed is a very cruel way of describing what is in fact walking away from large numbers of unemployed people and providing them with basic employment services.

As I said before, and I will not expand at this point, the cumulative effect of the government's bill, if enacted, is to set up this private market. What it means is that those persons who are not eligible—as the minister describes them—and who are not in receipt of unemployment benefits will end up having to pay a fee to an EPE or a PEPE to be competitive in that market. If two people go to an EPE looking for work, the EPE—as the minister says is her intention—will only be interested in helping the one who comes with the fee. If two people walk in the door and one person is going to provide $250 for receiving assistance and the other is just a person looking for work, it is quite clear what the EPE will do. They will assist the one with the fee attached.

Those people who are unemployed and not in receipt of assistance will have to pay to be competitive. If they do not match the $250, they are not in the market. The EPEs control the vacancies. They control who gets referred to an employer. The unemployed people are not dealing with the employer. They are dealing with an agency which has the right to decide whether or not they get referred to the employer.

So what we are setting up is a fee‐for‐service regime which means unemployed people have to pay for the right to get an interview for a job. I do not think that is a development this parliament ought to endorse. As I said, our amendment to the objects clause is designed to set up a different model which allows the government to do what it says its bill is about but prevents it from removing the services that are currently available to the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Evans, because the Democrats are jointly moving it with the Labor Party. I will just add a couple of things to Senator Evans's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the government can still argue universal access simply to the self-help facilities through the CSDA, and I expect the minister will argue that. But that does not, in our view, deal appropriately with the under‐employed, and I do not think we should leave the under‐employed out of our consideration here.

We have increasing casualisation of the work force. We have so many people in part‐time and casual work, not by choice but because it is all they can get. If the bill were to stand as it is, then people with working partners, part-time workers looking for more work, workers looking for alternative employment or students looking for part-time work—all people who are not in receipt of Department of Social Security allowances—would be excluded from access to anything but the most basic labour market assistance—as Senator Evans has outlined, looking at a touch screen and making a phone call.

The minister has argued that the government has only a certain amount of money to go around. That is because governments make choices about the balance between cutting expenditure and raising revenue. Even given that, you still have to ask yourself—given the state of employment in this country, with under‐employment and casualisation and the vulnerability of all those in this kind of work—whether it is fair to exclude those people. I think it excludes them from decent opportunities we have always offered in this country.

In the objects in the amendment, No. (i) has regard to the universality and No. (ii) seeks to include others than those on unemployment benefits. But Senator Evans did not touch on No. (iv). The last part of No. (iv) is:
. . . the right of users of the services to privacy—

This is an issue which is going to be debated at length as we go through the reform of the Public Service—that is, the whole notion of standards of privacy and accountability as things are contracted out to the private sector. We think the right of users of the service to privacy should be included in the objects of this act. I think these replacement objects more appropriately reflect what we think should be the thrust of the bill—which is universal access. We do not want confined services, the most basic labour market assistance or just self-help facilities at the CSDA; we want proper and additional services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly expand upon the point that Senator Kernot made about people who are under‐employed being denied assistance in this Reform of Employment Services Bill. Having represented people on low incomes in my previous role as a union official, I would have to say that, if you looked at the threshold level at which people will be denied access to labour exchange services under this bill, you would have to be concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures show that a couple with an income of $23,723 before tax would be denied access. That family could have a single salary earner or two part-time salary earners. If it was a single salary earner, the take-home pay would be about $366.50 a week, and I am sure those people would categorise themselves—and I think reasonably fairly—as the working poor. If they had the opportunity, I think they would be seeking to improve that level of income for the family.

They do pay tax, and may well have for some time, but this bill will deny them what they are now entitled to, that is, the opportunity for assistance to get alternative or additional employment so that they can meet their obligations and have a reasonable lifestyle. There is an unfairness in the proposition that these people be excluded from rights which they now have. It is absolutely incredible that the government is suggesting that one or both in the couple ought to be excluded from access to services which would assist them in seeking to find alternative or additional employment which might improve their position.

I refer to the issue of compliance with ILO convention 88. To me it is rather a long bow to suggest that the CSDA would provide services which comply with article 6. Because that is the only public sector body that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) proposes to establish, and having established it under other legislation but not establishing the PEPE under this legislation as a public sector body, the only organisation that anyone could look to to see whether the government was meeting its obligations under ILO convention 88 would be the PEPE. Article 9 says that the staff of the employment service shall be composed of public officials, et cetera. So it can be only the CSDA that purports to meet that test.

On the one hand, the department has said that it believes that it does meet that test. It says that they comply with the object. I guess we can take from that that, if they say they are complying with it, they do not really have an objection to it. On the other hand, if they do not comply with it, I suppose they are going to have a problem in respect of whether or not it is an object that would have potential for challenge. We think it is much better policy that the reference to the convention be contained in the objects because, in our view, that is a test which has to be transparently met in relation to the performance of this legislation. As I have said, looking at article 6 and the tests set down in article 6 for compliance, I think we would find this legislation wanting.

It is important to note how and why we developed the Commonwealth Employment Service in our previous commitment to ILO convention 88. After the Depression of the 1930s and the mass unemployment of that time, the government felt that they had an obligation to ensure that such unemployment would never be repeated. The CES was established in 1946 with the agenda of striving for full employment. To meet that end, a network of CES offices was established all over Australia.

The concept of a free employment exchange was so important then that, in 1949, member nations of the ILO, following the Declaration of Philadelphia, which established the ILO, set full employment as an objective for all nations. Australia was committed to free employment service for all Australians irrespective of where you live.

BREAK.PARA: To revert and say that the service delivery agency is meeting the tests of that convention is a statement which cannot in any sense be borne out having regard to the convention itself or the set of conditions that had been laid down in the service delivery agency bill and which will be established by this bill. It is important that the objects of the act reflect the appropriate public policy for this area. For that reason, I think we should support the amendment proposed by Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask Senator Evans a question about his amendment to clause 3 of the Reform of Employment Services Bill which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of this Act are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to establish mechanisms to deliver employment services, including employment assistance, in a manner which will ensure that—

TAB.TAB: (iii) employment services are provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner; and

SPEECH.PARA: Could Senator Evans advise the chamber whether that means that priority cannot be given to, for example, persons who are unemployed or long-term unemployed? What is actually meant by `employment services are provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to Senator Harradine that there is no suggestion in my amendment to the employment services bill which limits things in any way. It is an intention to provide an object which says that, where employment services are provided, they are provided in a fair, just and expeditious manner. It was inserted with a view to providing objects for the provision of services in the new employment market.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are attempting to do in the objects clause is to set out some standards and objectives which will need to be applied. It certainly is not the intention, nor is it the effect, to regulate how decisions are made about who receives employment assistance. Provided the services were provided in that manner, the amendment was designed to set out, as with the others, a view of what we regard as being important objects for any regime that was in place under this legislation.

It is certainly not intended to interfere in the decision as to which clients would be assisted for which services. I am not sure that it could be seen in that way. If someone had a contrary view, I would be happy to debate it. But it certainly was not the intention.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the government's provisions on page three of the legislation, what is the minister's view in respect of prioritising persons who attend for employment assistance under the employment assistance scheme? If, for example, there were two persons seeking employment and one had responsibility to provide for a number of dependent children from his or her income, is it the minister's view that those persons would be given priority over another applicant who did not have those responsibilities? Senator Evans might also comment on whether, under the opposition's proposals, such a person would be able to be given priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with my response generally to what people have said. Yes, it is true that we want to very severely constrain the spending of Commonwealth moneys other than for people who are long‐term unemployed or who are at risk of becoming long‐term unemployed. That is our intention. Yes, we do say that people who are on long‐term unemployment benefits will have first call on labour exchange money.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator O'Brien. There are significant hidden and underemployed people in Australia, as there probably are in any economy. They are hidden in the sense that people have stopped looking for work and they drop out of the labour force. They do not identify themselves as looking for work, but when things pick up they come back in. The underemployed people are working part time or shorter hours than they would want to. You are right; EPEs—employment placement enterprises—would not be paid by the Commonwealth for assisting those people.

BREAK.PARA: Can I explain to you why it was wrong? It was wrong for Martin Ferguson, the former president of the ACTU, to say last night, and it was equally wrong—and I would say more wrong—for Mr Beazley to say today that people will have to put their hands in their pockets to pay for employment services. It is wrong for two reasons. You might have raised the question of about to be made redundant workers in Newcastle, but certainly in New South Wales—and in South Australia where there is significant concern about National Rail—it is against the state law to charge an employee for employee placement services, and it has been for a significant period of time. In those states where it is not against the law, it is my understanding that there is a code of practice for private providers which prevents that.

More importantly, I will explain to you how these EPEs are going to work. If I wanted to set myself up as an employment placement enterprise—or as an arm of the public one, a PEPE—and I wanted to be successful, I would want to get as many unemployed people who are on benefits into jobs as I could because then the Commonwealth will pay me money. I want to get them into jobs. How am I going to do that? If I put out a sign to industry that says, `Come to me. I've got a lot of unemployed people. If you want one, come to me because I have got the best range of them possible', I suspect that I would be a complete failure. In fact, I would bet you London to a brick that I would be a complete failure.

On the other hand I recognise that to be successful I have to make industry links and that industry has to say, `Ring that Vanstone woman. She'll have someone for this particular job', whether it is a job in engineering, cleaning or whatever—the full range of activities. They may ring me up and want an engineer, but I have not got one. If I am the other fellow down the road who is behaving stupidly and only has unemployed people on benefits on my books and I do not have an engineer, then I am cooked. But if I have a wide range of people on my books—because I know that human resources is my business and that is what is important to the industry that I am dealing with—and they want an engineer, then I had better be able to give them one. If I have not got an unemployed engineer on benefits, I will give them one who wants more work or who is not on the benefit for some other reason. I will give them that first. But if I have an unemployed person on a benefit who is an engineer and I have others—someone underemployed, as you mentioned—then who am I going to pick first? The unemployed person on the benefit. That is what I mean by saying that we want to put them first in the queue.

In order to survive the EPEs will undoubtedly need to have a very broad range of people on their books. They will get payment from the Commonwealth for some and presumably they will get payment from industry for others. They may well say to industry—and I probably would if I was an employment placement provider—`Look, I haven't got someone who is on benefit as an engineer, but I've got another bloke who will fit your needs', or it could be a female these days because there are so many women engineers. If every time that industry rings up I comply with their needs, I give them what they need and I am a useful employment placement enterprise for them, they will keep using me.

When I offer them an unemployed person and say, `This person matches what you need', they will take him or her because I will have built up a trust with them and they will know that I will give them the people they need. So my best chance of getting more money from the Commonwealth is by giving industry what it needs. That will also mean that, as an employment placement provider, when I have a choice between sending along someone who has a job but would like more hours, and sending along someone who has not got a job but who wants one, I will send along the person who has not got a job and wants one. That is why I am so very pleased with this scheme, because it will put unemployed people on benefits first in the queue.

Lastly, in answer to Senator Harradine's question, I understand that it was not possible to include that as a characteristic when the case management services were set up and we have not included it as one. I have some sympathy with the prospect of looking at the conditions that a person might find themselves in if others are dependent on them, but I can see some difficulties associated with that. The short answer is that at the moment it is not a part of the government's plan. What would be looked at are the circumstances and the length of their unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points. Firstly, I confirm for Senator Harradine that I have checked and the clause he was referring to, subclause 3, was inserted in response to evidence at the community services committee inquiry where a number of groups like ACROD and other community based and religiously based service providers indicated that they had concerns to ensure that the new market provided some sort of protection for clients. And we have a range of amendments that go to that later on.

SPEECH.PARA: This is really putting into the objects clause that they be treated in a fair, just and expeditious manner. We are trying to put some principles behind how the market will operate for the protection of clients, because clearly they will not just be dealing with Public Service departments subject to the normal accountability measures that apply to Public Service authorities. They will be dealing with private companies set up to make profit. So it was thought important that the objects clause include that statement as part of the attempt to ensure those sorts of standards and values were applied.

In terms of the particular person being assisted, I guess my major point in relation to this amendment and the government's approach is to say that the government applies one rule when it comes to whether they are going to provide you with any assistance, be you single, with dependents or whatever—that is, are you registered for unemployment benefits? If you are not registered for unemployment benefits, you are on your own. You receive nothing from the government other than the equivalent of this slip of paper which comes out of their computer system at the agency, which will give you the address of the EPE to go and talk to about whether or not they will refer you to a job. That is all you will get from the government.

We are saying that there is a range of people who will not be registered for unemployment benefits, but who genuinely need assistance—who have dependents, who have responsibilities, who have needs that ought to be met by our community. The community should assist those unemployed people to be matched with vacancies to find work. That is what we seek to do. We do not seek to discriminate purely on the basis of whether you are entitled to unemployment benefits or not. We say that, if you need a job, then we ought to be providing some service to you.

The minister makes the point that she wants to ration services even further because of the costs involved. I just think that the costs to the community of having 400,000 people out there without assistance, without community support for finding jobs, is a cost that we should not pay and that they should not be forced to pay, and it is a basic community service obligation to assist those people.

The only other thing that I wanted to mention is that the minister seems to have taken issue with Mr Ferguson and, I gather now Mr Beazley, on this question of putting one's hand in one's pocket for a job. I just wanted to briefly say that the support for our proposition that people will have to pay EPEs to gain access to their services if they are not eligible job seekers—that is, not registered for unemployment—is taken directly from the minister's second reading speech where she gave credence to that by saying:
Under the legislation, EPES could not charge participants for providing them with employment assistance. This does not preclude EPES from charging non‐participants for similar services.

In other words, yes, they cannot charge eligible job seekers because the government is paying for them, but they can charge those not receiving benefits. In other words, she anticipates that the EPEs will have to charge those not receiving government support in order to get access to the same services, because she is creating this private market. I conclude her quote with the next line—I am not attempting to misquote her—where she says:

BREAK.PARA: This may provide an additional revenue source for EPES.

She clearly envisages setting up a market where the EPEs receive payment from the government for those who are receiving support as eligible job seekers, and receiving finance from other job seekers who will have to put their hands in their pockets to compete. And, quite frankly, no‐one believes that an EPE who has two or three different clients will refer the client who is not paying the money to an employer for an interview or job. Clearly, if the EPE is going to receive a minimum of $250 for referring one client and nothing for referring another client, they will refer the client who gives them the cash return—the very profit motive that the minister has extolled in the last hour or so.

Clearly, those who are not in receipt of government support will either basically get no support and have no chance of getting a job, or will have to put their hand in their pocket to get a job. It is a fee for service regime that has been established—make no mistake. You will have to pay for the privilege of an EPE referring you to an employer because the EPEs control the job. The new agency will not control the job. They will give you a slip of paper that says, `Here is the address of the EPE; go talk to them.' It is not a one‐stop shop at all; it is at least a two‐stop shop. The agency gives you the bit of paper. It says, `This EPE has a job'—the one I have got here is a hairdresser—but all you will get is the address of the EPE. It will be a closed vacancy because that is how they will make their money.

They will refer you to that EPE and the EPE will say to you, `That is very nice. Are you on any government assistance for seeking a job?' If you say no, I suspect they will show you their fee for maybe helping you with your CV or anything else. The minister refers to state legislation barring charging in a couple of states. That, I think, is putting the argument too strongly from my quick look at the legislation today but, in any event, that is not something controlled by us. What this legislation does—and the minister set this out in her second reading speech—is give us a regime where you pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to expand on what Senator Evans was saying with regard to some of the points raised by Senator Harradine, who is now not here, unfortunately. This legislation means that a casual school cleaner, for example, who has two or three kids and a non-working spouse and wants to become a full-time cleaner or access a full-time job will not be able to get free access to the labour exchange services. That is what this legislation means.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) acknowledges the increasing underclass of underemployed people and also those people who are stuck in poverty traps—and `poverty' is a word that is not used very much these days. The underemployed and those not getting sufficient income will not be able to access the same range of services that they do now. It is as simple as that, and that is the problem. That is why we have moved this amendment with regard to the objects of the act: to make sure that they do. We do not want underclasses in Australia. We do not want people who are on low wages ghettoised in those low wages; we do not want entrenched and systemic poverty traps existing in our country. That is the first point.

The second point I want to make—again, it is a pity Senator Harradine is not here; I might restate this point later when he returns—is that during some recent DEETYA Senate estimates hearings some Tasmanian senators sought a guarantee with regard to services by EPEs and PEPEs in Tasmania—it is a matter of great interest to you as well, Mr Temporary Chairman—because Tasmania is, first, the only island state; second, the most ruralised and disparate state in Australia; third, has the highest unemployment rate; and, fourth, has the highest youth unemployment rate. We sought a guarantee that services would be provided in the state, particularly where there are ghettos and pockets of high unemployment.

We could not get that guarantee from the department. We tried and tried assiduously to get that guarantee. What we were told, and the minister may like to comment on this, is, `We have a broad range of expressions of interest with regard to the EPEs and I can assure you, Senator, yes, there'll be no problem. There will be access to EPEs in Tasmania, particularly the areas of high unemployment.' Tasmanian senators are all too familiar with those areas. No commitment was given with regard to PEPEs. No commitment was given that, where there were no EPEs for whatever reason, a PEPE would be there to provide the service. No guarantee was given.

I would be interested to find out whether the minister is now prepared to give that guarantee because the problem with this legislation as it is currently constituted is that it does not provide a guarantee for regional Australia, it does not provide a guarantee for those areas of high unemployment and it does not provide a guarantee of services for those people who are attempting to better themselves in terms of income—those with dependants who want the choice that this government talks about in relation to changing employment or moving from casual employment to full-time or even part-time employment as an improvement.

First of all, I would be interested to see whether the minister can indicate that guarantee—and, even if she can, the only way we can be sure about it is to actually put the guarantee in the objects of the act.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of responses. As I have indicated, under I think about four state pieces of legislation they cannot charge. I have outlined the argument for why I think an employment placement enterprise will of course take an unemployed person first and put them in a queue. It is for placing an unemployed person on a benefit in a job that we will give them money for.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to whether I believe those states which have no legislation to prohibit charging will charge, the answer is no. As I have indicated to you, I believe there is an industry code—that has anecdotally been related to me. But, in any event, when there is some competition—and, Senator Evans, if you had a run in the private sector you might get a grasp of this—and one EPE says to someone who already has a job, `If you want me to get you a job with a few more hours, come to me but you will have to pay me to get you that job,' and another EPE down the road says, `You want a job with more hours; come on my books. If I can find one for you, I will put you into the spot. I won't put you ahead of an unemployed person but I want you on my books because you are my stock in trade. If the guy up the road is going to make you pay when he gets you a job, come on my books because I won't make you pay,' who do you reckon the person is going to go to? That is how it works.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know about the private sector, Minister. What do you think they are—charities?

—No, not charity, Senator. You probably have not spent a lot of time in the private sector either. In fact, you might have spent a lot of time in the CES and would be very keen to leave things as they are, but I am very keen to improve things. I believe that when there is some competition all unemployed people will get much better services. A key part of that is we will pay employment placement enterprises to put first the unemployed who are on benefits—and I would unashamedly put them first. I would put them ahead of someone who has a job and wants more hours, someone who has been out of work just for a while and someone who has a big redundancy payment and would like to shift quickly into another job. Our highest priority in this nation must be the long-term unemployed who are on benefits. They deserve our highest attention, and from this government they are going to get it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say—and I have the second reading speech here—nothing has changed in relation to employment placement enterprises. If an underemployed person walks into Drake Personnel to get some advice on how they can get some more work, Drake Personnel will talk to them about vocational guidance and charge them for a vocational guidance interview. If someone wants some help from Drake Personnel in preparing a resume, it will probably charge them for that too. It will do a couple of interviews and put them in the right place but, if that organisation then puts them into a job, it will charge the employer for that job. That is what happens now.

It takes a lot to take my breath away, but I have to say that when I see someone come in here and argue against the situation which has existed under the government that their party has been a part of for 13 years, I think, `Heavens, what's going on here?' This has been what has been happening.
An additional point needs to be made, and that is Senator Mackay wants an assurance, from what I can gather, that there will be a PEPE, a public employment placement enterprise, on every corner.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't say that.
—Whether they will be in every location.
—I said EPE or PEPE. I want a guarantee for regional Australia that they will have access to services by either an EPE or a PEPE.
—In every town?
—You define it. You are the minister.
—Exactly.
—You define it. You give the guarantee.
—Order! Minister, it might be—
—I am in fact trying to elicit from Senator Mackay what sort of guarantee she wants. She can see the stupidity of her question.
—No I can't.
—Well, Senator Mackay—

—Order! Minister, I will just interrupt you for a moment. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to update the Senate on the situation in Newcastle and the Hunter Valley following the announcement by BHP to downsize the steel industry in that area. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) met yesterday with the unions and a large group of workers from BHP in Canberra, where there was a very interesting exchange of views on the future of BHP in Newcastle and the Hunter Valley. The Prime Minister did find the whole experience very informative. The members of the unions and the workers did put forward in a very frank and very illuminating way some of the economic and social effects of the downsizing of BHP.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to correct an impression left by Peter Morris in the other place yesterday, and reported this morning in the Newcastle Morning Herald, about one aspect of that meeting which considered the future of the steel industry in the Hunter Valley. I must emphasise that the industry is staying in the Hunter Valley in the form of rolling steel products but not smelting steel. There will still be a steel industry in the Hunter Valley after the year 2000 but, of course, obviously of a much smaller size. In terms of the options for the future, Peter Morris, the member for Shortland, has put up the option of another company buying the plant. There has been another view put round that there should be a worker buy‐out. I just want to speak briefly on those two options.

The Prime Minister did express support for the fact that, if another company was prepared to buy the steelworks as an ongoing concern, he would support that. Indeed, I think both sides of the chamber would support that. I believe that about four years ago there was a prospective buyer for the steelworks in Newcastle. That prospective buy‐out actually fell through at that time. But, if a company from overseas or an Australian company came along and wanted to buy that steelworks as a going concern, I am sure we would all support it. What I would like to point out to the Senate, though, is that we should not get our hopes too high on that option. The probability of that happening, given the state of technology of that plant and given what is happening in world steel making at the moment, it is highly unlikely.

What is a particularly dangerous option, given what I have just said about the state of technology and the state of the world market, is suggesting to workers that they participate in a worker buy‐out. In a number of industries such an approach has worked and it has worked very successfully. There has been at least one case overseas in the steel industry where it has actually worked. But what people should realise is the run‐down in technology in the Newcastle plant, which has been running down over the last 25 years. If it was going to stay in Newcastle, BHP really should have built a very large new blast furnace in about 1972. They made the decision not to do that and, even despite Labor's steel plan, the net effect of that has been to patch up a very ageing steel plant whose technology has been passed by by new developments in steel making worldwide.

What would happen if there was a worker buy‐out is that people would be left with a plant which in a very short period of time would need a very major injection of capital. What BHP has done in its investment decisions with the Newcastle plant in recent years has been to inject enough capital to keep it running as an integrated steel mill until about the year 2000. Beyond that point, even if BHP stayed, it would need an absolutely major capital injection involving hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars, and people who got involved in such an arrangement could find that they would quickly lose their superannuation.

There have been a number of options put forward. Both of the options that the Labor Party seem to be following—either a worker buy‐out or someone else buying it—seem highly unlikely. It just amazes me that they continue with this backward looking approach. What we need in the Hunter Valley is a forward looking approach. As the region goes through a structural shift with the downsizing of BHP, we actually need to appreciate the social problems that that is going to cause, monitor that and actually respond in an appropriate way as a federal government.

That is why I was delighted yesterday when the Prime Minister announced the setting up of a high level prime ministerial task force to monitor this. He agreed to that with the union representatives yesterday. The task force will consist entirely of Hunter Valley people, who will be able to feed back directly to him the social ramifications of what is happening as time goes on, and then the government can respond appropriately to those problems. The federal government has already started to respond in an appropriate way to the economic situation created.

We have been examining a number of projects which will assist in the transformation of the work force and industry in the Hunter Valley. The Hunter Valley has a very bright future in a number of areas, but what is needed is a number of programs and certain infrastructure to help bring this about. Probably one of the brightest futures for the Hunter is in the area of tourism. Perhaps more than any other area of Australia it has a combination of natural and heritage assets that makes it an incredibly attractive tourist destination right on the doorstep of the largest city and major airport in Australia. That development will provide quite a lot of labour intensive jobs.

The other very bright future for the Hunter involves defence and defence related industry work. There is a large base which we would like to see develop into a super‐base for the air force. There are army facilities up there and increasingly naval work is starting to move to that area. It has a real potential not only for defence but for defence related contracts. This would help the Hunter move from the smokestack age that we have passed into a high‐tech future which creates real jobs; which creates high technology jobs; and which creates, through industries like tourism, labour intensive employment. It is that future that we have to look forward to, not back to the smokestack age, as the ALP would like us to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —This week I was pleased to be able to attend the launch of a report by Dr Murray Phillips entitled An illusionary image: a report on the media coverage and portrayal of women's sport in Australia 1996 . It was launched by the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, Warwick Smith, and the report highlights the fact that coverage and promotion of women's sport in Australia is still unacceptably low.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw a brief picture for this chamber of why this ridiculous anomaly continues to exist. It is an anomaly because this country has a long and proud sporting history but, unfortunately, part of this history has generally been excluded and the strengths, abilities and achievements of half the population have not been recorded with due diligence. In her book Half the Race, Marion Stell comments that `Australian women's success in international sport has been nothing short of astonishing when you consider the encouragement, resources, facilities and sponsorship directed elsewhere.' This is a very positive way of summarising what has been a very disturbing trend in Australian sport.

Shirley Strickland epitomises the struggle that Australian women who have excelled in sport have faced. Strickland, as a 23‐year‐old nuclear physicist, struggled to overcome public criticism about her skills and, later in her career, her age. She was a woman who won eight Olympic gold medals and paved the way for the international reputation Australian sports people now enjoy.

Strickland and the countless other women who have participated in international sporting events have also contributed to this reputation, but they have not, in my eyes, been given due recognition. For Australian women, sport has always been an all‐encompassing activity. By 1940, there were over one million women who belonged to a registered sporting association. The great thing about these sporting groups was that they were not restricted to any age group or social class.

Sport since colonisation of Australia has reflected societal prejudices and discrimination, but it has also provided an important medium for binding women of all ages and social status together. It has at times been a positive reminder of the strength of unity and the importance of advancing the women's movement.

In the 1920s, the added complexity of businesses becoming interested in women's sport emerged. Some motivation was based on physical fitness being correlated with more efficient workers. So women who had been in processing plants or standing on their feet all day were encouraged by their respective employers to take up hockey, lacrosse or athletics to strengthen their leg muscles. Badminton, table tennis, cricket and tennis were recommended for women working in factories to improve their hand‐eye coordination and, consequently, their output levels.

Many would argue that the shift from ladies being steered away from exercising due to the impropriety of it all would be a great thing for women. However, as many women have said, the shift had more to do with other people's agendas than their own. The emergence in the 1960s of television excluded women from the portrayal of sporting lifestyles that they had been inundated with, and so the catch‐22 for women's sport was born— women needed sponsorship to get television coverage and advertising, but advertising companies would not give sponsorship without television coverage.

This problem has continued to date with sponsors and companies requiring input into promotional aspects of their sport and uniform design. With so few women holding senior positions in large companies—and I think the current figure for women holding positions on corporate boards is, in fact, only three per cent—combined with only 21 per cent of executive directors of sporting organisations being women, the problem of fair and equi table participation of women in the sporting arena does become just a bit more difficult.

So what does this mean for the new generation of female athletes? The report by Dr Phillips indicates that, if they watch TV or listen to the radio, they will rarely—only two per cent of the total air time—see or hear about women achieving in sports. What young women do see and hear a lot about is men participating in great sports such as rugby league, golf, soccer, cricket, rugby union, et cetera. Some of these sports have women's teams or competitors and, certainly, a lot of fans, but few women get a look in with respect to this coverage.

What else do women see in the sports arena? They see very few female coaches. Recent statistics show that only 29 per cent of level 1 coaches are women and 17 per cent and 11 per cent are level 2 and level 3 coaches respectively. Here in Canberra, only two of the 24 head coaches are women—that is, eight per cent—and nine out of the 54 other coaches are women. This is cause for concern because the report highlights a very interesting point. That is, out of all the factors that contribute to what inspires women to contri‐

BREAK.PARA: bute in sport, to stick with a sport and to achieve in a sport, one is the attitude of their coach and their relationship with their coach who is leading them through the sport and encouraging them.

Recently, the minister for sport expressed his surprise at this low coverage level of women's sport, but I do not think you really have to look too far beyond some of the weekend sporting shows to see that this is in fact a reality. I am hoping that, arising out of this report, we will see some active campaigning on behalf of the government to rectify this problem. It is a tough one because it is not just about berating the media and saying, `Cover more women's sport,' but about improving women's involvement right through all the levels in sports administration.

The media do have a significant role to play and do need to take some responsibility for what is going on, but I think the government can also do a lot to encourage them in this direction. This report is an important step in, once again, highlighting this problem, and it was certainly initiated in a formal report when Senator Rosemary Crowley was involved and initiated this program in the first instance.

I think the time has come for the Australian public, advertisers, companies, sporting bodies and all media to recognise the strengths and abilities of women's sport in this country and the fact that people do actually want to watch it. If they extended themselves and perhaps experimented with greater coverage of women's sport in prime time television or radio slots, they would be very surprised at the high degree of support that they would get back from the Australian community in this regard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 April, 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How much revenue was raised through the Prescribed Payments System (PPS) in the 1993‐94, 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) what is the anticipated revenue from this source in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(2) Is this system of taxation collection designed to apply only to bona fide contractors in a limited number of industries.

(3) (a) How many contractors paid tax through this system in the 1993‐94, 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) what is the estimated number of taxpayers through this system in the 1996‐97 financial year.

(4) (a) What was the share of the total tax revenue contributed by PAYE taxpayers in the 1993‐94, 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) what is the estimated contribution to tax revenue by this group in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(5) Were changes to the operation of the PPS announced in the 1995‐96 Budget statement; and (b) what was the nature of those changes.
(6) What was the anticipated impact on the number of contractors using the system and taxation revenue from the proposed changes.

(7) Were those changes abandoned in the 1996‐97 Budget; and (b) was this decision based upon advice from the Australian Taxation Office and or the Treasury; if not, what was the basis for this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The revenue collected through the PPS is as follows: 1993‐94—$1,871m; 1994‐95—$2169m; 1995‐96—$2179m.
(1) (b) It was estimated in the 1996‐97 Budget that revenue collections from PPS would be $2200m.

(2) PPS applies to payments made to contractors who are not common law employees working within one of the following industries: building and construction; road transport; motor vehicle repairs; joinery and cabinet making; architectural; engineering; surveying; other professional building and construction services and cleaning. The payments must be intra‐industry, ie., they must be made and received by persons or businesses operating within the same industry category.

(3) (a) The number of contractors, which includes individuals, companies, trusts and partnerships, that paid tax through the PPS are as follows: 1993‐94—399,386; 1994‐95—429,549; 1995‐97—353,373 (YTD, processing incomplete).
(b) No estimates are made of the number of people expected to pay tax through the PPS in 1996‐97
(4) (a) The share of tax revenue collected through the PAYE is as follows: 1993‐94—60.4%; 1994‐95—58%; 1995‐96—57.2%
(b) It was estimated in the 1996‐97 Budget that the share of revenue collections from PAYE would be 62% of all tax revenue.
(5) There were no changes to the operation of the PPS announced in the 1995‐96 Budget statement.
